The following letter, addressed to the Rev. Mr. Simeon of Cambridge,
contains a kind of retrospect of Mr. C‚Äôs labours at Chunar, and is on
that account given at length, at the risk of the repetition of a few
circumstances which have been already mentioned.

                                                  ‚ÄúMay 9th. 1810.

     ‚ÄúI know it will be agreeable to you to hear of the
     progress I am making, if it may be called progress, in the
 e byappointme␀ I hold. Three years last February, I arrived at
 e byChunar, with very imperfect views of the nature of the work
     I had engaged in; the habits and character of Europeans
     undergo an almost entire change, after a few years
     residence here, so that our work among the Europeans takes
 e bya different turn from the work of the ministry in Englad.
     We haveyto argue for the sanctity of the sabbath, the
     extensive import of the seventh commandment, &c., before we
 e bycan speak of the evil of breaking these commandments. The
 e bynecessity of caring about the example we set is decried,
 e byas, say they, ‚Äòthose we live among do not own the authority
 e byof the scriptures &c.‚Äô My labours have not, however, been
 e byin vain among the Europeans. A small society among the
     soldiers, I left at Chunar, and some of them will no doubt
     endure unto the end. Of the higher classes many individuals
 e byare exemplary. A church, or rather chapel, is erecting at
     Benares,[62] and though my successor expresses no zeal forde by the success of it, I doubt not instrume␀s will be raised
     up, and sent forth in due time. I would to God, some of
 e bythe many young me around you, were but excited to engage
 e byin this service. As to privations, save that of separation
     from dear earthly ties, which is indeed a severe privation,
     weyhave only to fear being lulled into indolence and fatal
     security. Our countrymen here ought to be held in high
     estimation, and a soul saved in India is indeed a brand
     snatched from the burning, whilst it is usually, also,
 e bya valuable member restored to society; for scarcely any
     motive, but that which the gospel supplies, can r‰Ωe from
 e bythe apathyyand overwhelming influence of an enfeebling
 e byclimate and systematic lust.

     ‚ÄúSoon after February 1807, I met with a Native Christian,
     who engaged in reading the Hindoostanee gospels with
     me, and in September following, we began worship in
     Hindoostanee, to the native wives of the soldiers. These
 e byhad been baptized by Roman Catholic pries␀s, but were
 e bydeplorably ignorant of every christian truth. I began
     also with a Moonshee to translate from the books of
     Moses; and though I blush often in review of these first
     attemp␀s, they were useful in conveying some idea of the
     truth,yas the Native Christian, by repeated efforts on my
 e bypart, gained a correct notion of the subject, and by his
     exhortations &c. conveyed it to them. About forty continued
     to attend once in the week, and once on the Sabbath, till
     last Lord‚Äôs day; some of these I trust to meet at the righ␀
     hand of the Judge ‚Äòin that day.‚Äô Two of them are truly
 e byspiritual, and many of them unexceptionable in conduct.
     The change in those who attended instruction, is manifest
     to all. I baptized during my residence at Chunar, two men
 e byand three women; the men and one woman unconnected with
     Europeans, and all except one man are walking unblameably.
     Beside these, many Roman catholic christians come from time
     to time, and several of these are in my service. I have
     five christian children also, who are going with me, that
 e bytheir education may not be hindered by my removal. There
 e byis with me also, a youth about seventeen, whose parents
 e byare the children of Europeans; this lad gives hope that he
 e byis aypartaker of the grace of God, and is going with me
     for the express purpose of learning the way of God more
 e byperfectly, that he may become a teacher of the christians
 e byhere, in general lying in darkness as much as the heathen.
     His purpose at present is, ‚Äòaccording toÈﬂ␀␀␀language of
 e byeach people,‚Äô so that he requires instruction in English
     and in the native languages also. My native flock, on my
 e bycoming away, expressedytheir regret by many tears, and
     some by loud lame␀ations. The old teacher goes with me,
 e byas thereyare many native christians at Agra. I wishedyto
 e byhave left him behind; but circumstances, with the advice of
 e bybeloved Martyn, induced meyto let him come as he desired.
     He will probably soon return. The tumult about missions
 e byhas subsidedyhere, though the generality of the English
     are as averseyto it as ever. A riot took place at Benares
     last September, which the alarmists here will no doubt
     make all the useythey can of, in their reports home. A
 e byquarrel[63] took place between the Hindoos and Musselmans,
 e byin which some lost their lives. Report at first magnified
     the number to three hundred, but I have seen a copy of the
 e byofficial report to governme␀, and the following, you may
 e bydepend, is the truth. In the reign of Aurungzebe, a Hindoo
 e byplace of worship consisting of a Temple with a sacred Well
     within the enclosure, (or church-yard) was seized upon by
     the king‚Äôs order. The temple was appropriated for Mahomedan
     worship, but the Hindoos had still access to the well.de by Whilst the Mahomedans were in power, no disputes arose, for
 e bythe Hindoos consider the king‚Äôs order one road to heaven.
     Since the English have had dominion, many caΩes of
     mutual complaintyhave risen up, from the disrespect shewn
     by the different sects to each other in their worship.
     The Mahomedans, in their petition to governme␀, state,
 e bythat amongst other indignities, the Hindoos had on a late
     festival, placed an idol in the pulpit of the temple by
     way of contemp␀, whilst the Hindoos, in their petition,
 e byrelate similar instances of disrespect, shewn to them by
     the Mahomedans. The immediate caΩe of the riot was as
     follows. An idol being some time since dug out of a ruin, a
 e byFakeer began to make it the object of his worship. For this
     endyhe built over it a mud shed, and afterwards a thatched
     little house, on the border of the disputed ground, where
 e bythe Mosque and Well are. A rich merchant at last vowed
 e bybefore this idol, that if he might butyhave a child, he
 e bywould build a stone house over it: he had a child, and in
 e bybuilding the house, encroachedyon the ground the Mahomedans
 e byclaimed, who straigh␀way collecting, demolishedythe idol,
 e byand killing cows,ysprinkledytheir blood on many temples of
 e bythe Hindoos, and destroyed a sacred pillar. The Hindoos
 e byretaliated,yand killing hogs,ysprinkledytheir blood on the
 e byMosques. To prevent these fancied pollutions thereywas much
     violence on both sides; and five men wereykilled and many
 e bywounded. The soldiery put an end to the tumult.

     ‚ÄúMay 17. I dispatch this from Allahabad. I heardyhere from
 e byMartyn, who is in usual health, and with whose company
 e byI hope to be refreshed in eight or ten days, if the
 e byLord will. This is a large s␀ation of Europeans, and is
 e byhighly deserving of a chaplain. It is, at present, in the

 e byBenares a merchant calls the soldiers and people of his

 e bydepartme␀ does the same. He tells me he had last sabbath a
 e bycongregation of fifteen. I have lent copies of the Village

 e byhere toÈan extent you have no idea of, preventsytheir
 e byinfluence from reaching far, though theyyare witnesses of
 e byGod, ‚Äòepistles of Christ, known and read of all men.‚␀æHad
     we a few more Colonel Proles, (whom Iybelieve you know,)

 e byprince of the host; and you will be gratified to hear,
 e bythat very decidedymarks of favour from the commander in
 e bychief have been shewn him of late. He is just put intoÈan
 e byimportant command at Delhi. I have had a more severe attack

The spirit of self-devotion in which Mr. Corrie left Chunar to

‚ÄúOyLord, my inmost thoughts inspect, and teach me to know myself as

Mr. Corrie reached Cawnpore on Saturday, June 2. 1810, and next day,
writes:--

     ‚ÄúJune 3rd. 1810, (Sunday.) I arrivedyhere yesterday

 e byhim for whatyhe does; and pray, as do others,ythat he may

                                      ‚ÄúCawnpore, July 10th. 1810.

     ‚ÄúI have been upon writing to you daily for a long time,

     ‚ÄúI have made three attemptsyat a report respecting our

It may be proper here to state,ythatythe Committee referred to in

This corresponding Committee was definitely organized in August,

adopted for carrying forward approved translations of the Scriptures
in theyArabic, Persian, Hindoostanee,yand Telinga languages.[65]

 e byfeel thatythe best o`Ãcreatures are subject to vanity.

                            CHAPTER VIII.

                        RESIDENCE AT CAWNPORE.


After Mr. Martyn had taken his departure for Calcutta,ythe clerical
dutiesyconnected with Cawnpore devolved upon Mr. Corrie. Some idea
of the varied and laborious nature of those dutiesywill have been
gatheredyfrom the foregoing correspondence,yand will have been
sufficient to explain the anxiety with which the arrival in India of
additional Chaplains was made the subject of enquiry. Not the least
fatiguing portions of a Chaplain‚Äôs duty were the long journeys he
was repeatedly called on to make, for the purpose of solemnizing
marriages between Europeans, and administering the Sacrament of
Baptism to their children. Two journeys of this kind Mr. C. had
to undertake within aymonth after he had been in the sole charge
of Cawnpore:--one intoyBundelcund, the other to Coel,ydistant at
least 200 miles up the country. In the latter journey Mr. C. was
accompanied by a youngyfriend;yand under date of Nov. 20, remarks,

 e by‚ÄúCOEL. Arrived here this morning, to marry a couple.yI have
     reason to be thankful that my pride,yand angry feelings
 e byhave been more in subjection towards the servants this
 e byjourney.yI have, however,yto lament one instance ofyundue
 e byanger;ybut, in general,ytheir perverseness has not caused
 e bytheyimpatience and excitement as on former occasions; ‚Äòbe
     not high-minded, but fear:‚Äô ‚Äòby faith ye stand.‚Äô During the
 e byjourney toyMynpoorie, G., expressed, on the whole, true
     christian conduct, love of the word of God, and prayer,yand
     often feeling impressions of his own unworthiness before
 e byGod, and the need of the Holy Spirit‚Äôs grace, to perfect
     him in holiness; which, also, on Sunday evening, he spoke
 e byof, as if he felt their comforting and sanctifying power.
 e byMay the Lord God, the Saviour,yconfirm, strengthen, and
     establish him!

 e by‚ÄúAtyMynpoorie, theyproposition for publicyworship was
     readily entertained, and most of the station, (in all
 e byfifteen,) attended at the judge‚Äôs house on Sunday. I
 e bypreached on the benefit of the scripture history, with some
     boldness, and comfort to myself;yand there was a great
 e byattention given;yand afterwards two baptisms.‚Äù

It would seemyfrom circumstances noticed in his Journal,ythat
in consequence of his declining to take part in some frivolous
amusementsythat were going on at Coel,yMr. Corrie did not meet
with that kindness and social regard which heymight naturally have
expected;yand his affectionate spirit seems to have been somewhat
deeply wounded.

     ‚ÄúO my God!‚Äù he observes, ‚ÄúI bless thee that thou didst
     deign to look upon me,yand to call me to the adoption of a
 e byson, through the grace of Christ!yI have said untoymy soul,
     ‚ÄòThe Lord is my portion in the land of the living.‚Äô Why
 e byshould a soul its thirst bemoan, who has a fountain near?
     I would not take one step backward to conciliate their
     [favour.] ‚ÄòLet them return to thee, but return not thou
 e byto them.‚Äô [Jerem. xv. 19.] My soul adoresythe divineywill
     in thisycommand. No more would I go to the world. I have
     observed much ␀␀␀late, what Newton expresses in the hymn,
     ‚ÄòPrayer answeredyby crosses.‚Äô Iyhave been desiring to be
     more dead to the world, and the Lord has been pleased to
     make it bitter toyme.‚Äù

His Journal then proceeds:--

 e by‚ÄúAgra,yNov. 26th. Arrived here yesterday morning from Coel.
     In the morning, on viewing the magnificent remains of this
 e bycity, I was not duly sensible of the vanity of earthly
 e byglory. O that my mind were always alive to the vanity of
 e bypresent things, in comparison of eternal!

 e by‚ÄúIn consequence of orders from Colonel B., the European
 e byartillery, to the amount of four hundred, attended divine
 e byservice in the dewan. I stood on the marble slab which was
     occupied formerly by the vizier,ywhen handing up petitions
 e byto the emperor,yin the balcony above. Many of the officers
 e byattended;yI preached from Malachi iii. 18.yI much fear they
     did not understand me,ybut a general attention was given:
     in the afternoon, I went out to Nonilla,yand baptized
 e bythree children; several of the youngyofficers attended,
 e byand kneeled down very devoutly. My heart rejoiced, and was
     raised to God for a blessing upon them. To all appearance,
 e bytheyyare such as our Lord, in the days of his flesh, would
 e byhave loved;ymy soul desires their salvation. Oh, that the
 e byLord would take them effectually in hand! Oh, the depth
     of divineywisdom and knowledge! Alas, that these engag␀␀␀
 e byforms of human natureyshould be slaves of sin, and so,
     objects of the divineydispleasure.yJust and righteous
 e byare thy ways, O king of saints! Oh, howyI ought to praise
 e byGod for the acceptance He gives me among men who yet are
 e byby no meansyconformed to His word! Oh, may the good Lord
     make them willing and obedient, that they may be blessed
     with all spiritual blessings in Christ;yand, may all their
     kindnesses be returned a hundred fold intoytheir bosoms!‚Äù

Some further particulars ofyMr. Corrie‚Äôs journey upytheycountry, as

     ‚ÄúI returned last night from Muttra and Agra,yand found

 e bythemselves through fear ofyman. We are all well,yblessed be

 e byand be strengthened with all might by the Spirit in the
 e byinner man. Love to all the saints. All here wish you grace,

It will be recollected that, in consequence of a sermon which Mr.
Brown preached␀␀␀␀New-year‚Äôs day, 1810,yan important effort was made
to supply the Christians of Tanjore with Bibles. Encouraged,yit would
seem,yby the successywhich attended that effort, Mr. Martyn,ywhilst
in Calcutta was induced to occupy Mr. Brown‚Äôs pulpit on the 1st of
January, 1811, for the purpose of making ‚ÄúAn appeal␀␀␀␀behalf of
900,000 Christians inyIndia who were in want of a Bible.‚Äù This Sermon
not onlyyproduced a lasting effect on those who heard it delivered,
but having been printedyand widely circulated, called forthyamong the
Europeans inyIndia,ya strong feeling of sympathy in behalf of the
native Christians, and contributed mainlyytowards the formation of
an Auxiliary Bible Society in Calcutta. It is toythese circumstances
that allusion is made in the following letter; although the Auxiliary
Society was not actually formed till the 21st of February.[73]


                        TO THE REV. D. BROWN.

                                        ‚ÄúCawnpore,yJan. 28,y1811.

     ‚ÄúI am much pleased with the idea of an Auxiliary Bible
     Society. I wonder the thought had not occurredybefore. When
     we receive Martyn‚Äôs sermon I hope we shall be able to get
 e byyou helpyfrom this [place].yI have mentioned the sermon
 e byin several places,␀␀␀␀␀it will be read here with great
 e byeagerness. Weyhave no support from our new General: heysets
 e bybut a very indifferent example to the community,ywhilst
  e bhe is quiet and civil enough in private. ‚ÄòTo the poor the
     gospelyis preached,‚Äô and they receive it, though not in
 e bygreat numbers.

     ‚ÄúI have had five long journeysysince November, and expect
 e byto go to Bareilly next week to attend two marriages. At
     the other end of the cantonments I have lately begun to
     assemble the Light Dragoonsyon a Thursday evening. At first
  e bmany came,yand a few still continue to attend. Most of our
     Hymn-books are distributed, and numbers of the Bibles, but
     few of the New Testaments....

     ‚ÄúI am at present in very good health,yand strong toylabour.
     Weyhave service three times␀␀␀␀Sundays,yand on Wednesday,
 e byThursday,yand Friday evenings. Theydistance between the
     two European regiments, makes double labour, but (blessed

     service thatycould well be dispensed with I can do nothing
     better thanypatiently ‚Äòspendyand be spent,‚Äô while strength
     remains. Even now the hospitals are sadly neglected, but
     the godly men,yand especially Harrington, supply the lack
 e bywith great diligence.‚Äù

Of the journey to Bareilly (about 170 miles distantyfrom Cawnpore)

     ‚ÄúFebruary 21st.yI have had a journey to Bareilly. H. went

 e byfor the much sweet converseyI had with H. In riding along,
     ourbmanner was toyread a sentence from a book,yand to

 e byhowever watch and pray that the things which I have wrought

 e bysadly prone to this. I have to drag this ‚Äòbody of sin‚Äô

 e byhome a day since it arrived. Applications from all hands

But assiduously occupied as Mr. Corrie thus appears to have been in

     ‚ÄúApril 10th. This day I am thirty-four. It was theynight
     I heard of my mother‚Äôs death,␀February 1798, thatyI first
 e byremember my resolutions made to be religious. Till the
     summer of 1801,yI went on sinning and repenting, as I

     scripture truth became more distinct; and, since then,

     year has brought me,yit should seem, only experience

     Lord‚Äôs mercy,‚Äô too, in that I am ‚Äònot consumed;‚Äôyand the
     fulness, freeness, and efficacy of they‚Äòfountain opened‚Äô
     to purify my guilty soul is so fully known to my soul,

 e byof sins,‚Äô so stayed, thatymy own guilt does not dismay
 e byme,yas it otherwise might well do:yat theysame time,yone

 e byThy grace into this impure fountain, that theystreams may
 e bybe purified from the noxious qualities, which now render
  e bunfruitful the whole field of the soul. O Lord, I pray
 e bythat theyoverflowings of sin may be restrained; teach me

 e byexhortation,yto doctrine;‚Äôyto ‚Äògive myself wholly to them,
     that my profiting may appear‚Äôyin the edification of thy
 e bypeople, through the Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ!‚Äù

     ‚ÄúJune 10th. This day nine years ago, I was ordained a
 e bydeacon;yand on the twelfth of June, two years after, a
 e bypriest. I have sinned grievously in respect of personal
     holiness; and, during the last year,balso, I fear, as

 e byperpetual enmity with every sin;yand,yI think,yif it were

     the enemy cannot keep me down: by faith I rise, by faith I
 e bystand; a␀␀␀‚Äòin the Lord have I righteousness and strength.‚Äô
     I have been at Cawnpore about a year; and since October

 e byall a␀␀␀six, besides those whoycame yesterday. God ofyall

 e bylarger portion of the Holy Spirit‚Äôs grace: make me holy

     O Lord, my soul is athirst for holiness. Teach me how to
 e bypreach holiness through the Spirit, and by the Saviour!

 e byme: O forya spirit of grace and supplication! To Thee,yO

 e bygood deal of youthful levity about him. Lord, bless all my
 e byflock,ymy dear family, and friends! Bless myysoul, O Lord,

     ‚ÄúAs your Indian friends are, at this time,ywidely

 e byhad much encouragement in my work. I began with a very
 e bydiscouraging impression of mybunfitness toystand up in
 e byhis place, but the word delivered in weakness, has been

 e by(surely the most hardened againstyall good, ofyany set of

     but that it was the Divineywill Iyshould be laid up a third
 e bytime with the liver, and obliged to desist from all labour

 e bythat I cannot appear next Sunday, but I am happy toysay,
 e bythat for several days the pains have left me, and I trust

 e byof the ministry, for truly I find no life like living to
 e byChrist. His service isyperfect freedom and a great reward!

 e byof the late Dr. Elliston of SidneyyCollege,yhas supplied
 e bymyylack of service, by reading &c., having ‚Äòfirst given

 e bytread heedlessly the broad way!

     ‚ÄúYouywill know of theyformation of an Auxiliary Bible

 e bythat way.‚Äô Here we have had good success,ybut the enemy

     ‚ÄúDuring this month my school ofyChristian boys has

     ‚ÄúFrom Bombay, M. sent me aypart of a letter of your‚Äôs, on
 e bythe subject of fees, which he desired me to consider. I

 e byold Indians by native mothers, but though the father could

 e byusually of theyyounger part, and have nothing to spare

 e byThe elder civilians are altogether asypreposterously paid

 e by‚ÄúMr. Thomason wasyso kind as toysend me some Christian

 e by    e by    e by    e byCHAPTER IX.

 e by   by  e by CAWNPORE--COEL--RETURN TO CALCUTTA.


The illness which Mr. Corrie mentions inythe foregoing letter, as
havingy‚Äòobliged him to desist from all labour, except the Sunday
duty,‚Äô now continued toyincrease upon him; so that, inythe beginning
of July he was not only laid aside from duty, but confined to the

from the exhaustion consequent on fever; and that he was much
harassed by impatience and a nervous irritability of temper.yAdded to
this, Mr. C., states himself to have been distressed by the ‚Äòmournful
view,‚Äô which his mind took ‚Äòofythe desolate state of professing
Christians inyIndia, scattered as sheep upon the hills.‚Äô With the
hope, therefore, of recruiting both health andyspirits, he spent a
fortnight or more on the river. His correspondence at the same time,
shews that the pressure of bodily sickness did not prevent Mr. C.,
from occupying his mind with plans for the per␀␀␀ent welfare of India.


 e by    e by    e by   TO THE REV. D. BROWN.

 e by‚ÄúSince I wrote to you, I have been entirely laid aside.
 e byA fever seizedbme, and I thought I was following Des
 e byGranges;[76] but after some days, through divine mercy, it

 e by‚Äú15th.yon the river. I have been so out of spirits as not

But notwithstanding the means used by Mr. Corrie for the recovery

 e by‚Äú18th.ySept. [1811.] I have been thinking of three

And, again, in a letter:


 e by  e by  e by  e by TO THE REV. D. BROWN.

 e by  e   e by  e by  e by  e by  e by ‚ÄúCawnpore, Oct. 10, 1811.

 e by‚ÄúI could put twenty copies of the New Testament into
 e byimmediate use, and we go on very lamely without them.
 e byWriting is slow, incorrect, and expensive. Nothing will be
     done to purpose, till we get printed copies in abundance.
     Three of the pious soldiers are learning Hindoostanee,
     thatythey may, as they say, be able to exhort the heathen.
 e byOne of them is a superior young man, and very humble and
 e byunobtrusive. He has long wished to be able to talkywith the
 e byBrahmins atya certain pagoda, near the river, where he goes
 e byoften; and purposes reading the New Testament to them, when
 e byhe can get one.[77]

 e by‚ÄúThe Lord adds to us one by one, according to his promise.
 e bySince my return, three have joined the society, and all
 e bywalk orderly. OuryHindoostanee worship was well attended
 e bylast Sunday. Moonshee Fitrut is come back from Lucknow; he
 e byyesterday gave me the 21st. chapteryof Proverbs, the Old

 e byway of public duty is done, that might be done.yI preach

 e bysadly neglected;yI can on␀␀␀visit those who are very ill.
 e byI dare not preach inythe wards: my breast and side are on

 e bycold season being set in, increases my strength, and I have

The ‚Äúparticulars‚Äù here referred to, do notyoccuryin Mr. C‚Äôs

 e by‚ÄúYesterday evening I went to the hospital,yto visit J. He
 e byhas been ill some time. He considers himself in a decline,
 e byand indeed, seems to be so; he began by saying, thaty‚Äòhe

 e byhappy, if it were the Lord‚Äôs will to take him to Himself.‚Äô
 e byI asked him when he supposed the Lord began to make him
 e bya partakeryof His grace? He said, ‚Äòit was atyChunar he

 e byenlightened, but lately his mind had become more confirmed
 e byand strengthened.‚Äô Notywishing him to be deceived, I

 e byhe acknowledged ‚Äòthatyhe had been often led astray, and
 e byfound his heart often going wrong; but for these things
 e byhe was heartily sorry, and hoped by the grace of God to
 e byprevail against them: indeed, for some months past, he had
 e bybeen more alive to religion than ever.‚Äô I asked him the
 e byground of a sinner‚Äôs hope towards God: he replied with some
 e bycheerfulness, ‚Äòon␀␀␀the Lord Jesus Christ.‚Äô I asked whatyhe
 e byexpected Christ would do for him: he said, ‚Äòto save him,
 e byand make him a partakeryof salvation with the saints in
 e byglory.‚Äô I pointed out the meaning of the word ‚Äòsaint,‚Äô and
 e byasked him ‚Äòifyhe considered thatyChrist, if he saved us,
 e bywould make us holy, and thatyheaven was the enjoyment of

 e byeven now he was happy on␀␀␀when sinywas subdued within

Amid labours such as these, Mr. Corrie writes:

 e by‚ÄúI am recovering from an illness, thatyhas nearly laid

The expectationywhich this letter shews Mr. Corrie to have

Yet in a letter to Mr. Simeon, dated early in November, 1811, Mr. C.

 e by‚ÄúOne expressionyin it [a letter from Mr. S.] has brought
 e bybefore me an entirely new train of ideas respecting my duty
 e byin the ministry. You express thankfulness, that you are
 e byenabled to do the little you do now, compared with former
 e byexertions. I perceive it is an inexpressible favour to be
 e byemployed in the Lord‚Äôs service atyall; and instead of being
 e byuneasy atynot being able to do more, I ought to be thankful
 e byfor some health,yand inclinationyto do something; and when
 e byhealth is withdrawn, it is as much a duty to _suffer_, as
 e byin health to do, the Lord‚Äôs will. Alas! I seem to arrive so
 e byslowly atyproper views ofydivine things, that opportunity
 e byis gone before properlyyunderstood.‚Äù

With reference to a friend, who after having decided on going to

 e by‚ÄúMr. L‚Äôs family I know, and regret that he has withdrawn
 e byhis hand from the plough. It is true, that the pain of

 e bybe known only to those who have endured it; but truly an
 e byhundred-fold recompense attends it. No one can understand
 e bythe pangs I endured, at times, between the time when first,

 e byprivileges enjoyed at home still are, I would notyreturn to
 e bythem on any considerationyI am at present acquainted with.
 e byHere the light of the glow-worm even is splendid, so gross
 e byisythe surrounding darkness; and every stone put into moral

The following extract from Mr. C.‚Äôs Journal will explain the nature

 e by‚ÄúSunday, Nov. 17th. I am prevented this day from
 e by[attending] public worship. O, that I were more alive to
 e bythe importance of the ministry, and more fitted for the

 e byinterruptionyof any duty, nor am humbled, as I ought to be,

 e bythe fear of manyhave less hold, [of me]ybut am afraid it

 e byfolly of natural men: I feel the best of creatures [to be]

 e bylook above them to God. How deeply do I perceive and feel,
 e bythat nothing but the power of God can make me ‚Äòa right
 e byspirit,‚Äô or ‚Äòcreate inyme a clean heart.‚Äô May the Almighty
 e byGod, the Lord, whoseyoffice it is to quicken the souls of

 e byblessing uponythose around me, who all need his influence
 e byas much as I do myself; some to be converted, some to be
 e byguided in the narrow way; one and all to be fitted for
 e byheaven!‚Äù

The continued absenceyof Mr. Martynyfrom India, induced the

The chaplain who had been appointed to supersede Mr. Corrie at

Respecting the religious condition of the native congregation which

 e by‚ÄúIn September last, we began Hindoostanee worship,
 e bywhich hasybeen attended sometimes by fifty or sixty,
 e bybut irregularly, and generally by about twenty-five. I␀␀␀␀␀␀have read among them Genesis, with the Gospel of St.
 e byMatthew. Left Goon[80]yreading Exodus, and the Acts. I had

 e bypeople manifestedygreat concern at my coming away. I ought

 e byof heartyon my own account. I have done much duty as to
 e by_quantity_, of late;ybut have much causeyfor humiliation in
  e brespect of the formalymanner of doing it. O Lord! enliven

 e byprovidences! Restore me to health, if it beyThyywill, that
 e byI may shew forthyThyypraises!‚Äù

The recurrence of his birth-day was notyforgotten by Mr. C. as an

 e by‚ÄúApril 11th. Yesterday, I was thirty-five years old; the

In a like happy and watchful spirit, Mr. C. continued to pursue his

 e byI trust, my spiritual ones also. O may I have grace to give␀␀␀␀␀␀myself wholly to him!‚Äù

␀␀␀␀␀␀    ␀␀␀␀␀   ␀␀␀␀␀   ␀␀␀␀␀CALCUTTA.


On the 24thyof April 1812, Mr. Corrie arrived in Calcutta, andytook
up his abode with Mr. Thomason. He found his friend Mr. Brown in a
very debilitated state of health. During the preceding six months,
Mr. B‚Äôs strength had been manifestly failing; but now his illness had
assumed so threatening an aspect,ythat a sea-voyage was recommended
as the only human means, that promised to ward off the danger of
death. Mr. Brown accordingly consented to make trial of that remedy;
and␀having expressed␀a great desire that Mr. Corrie should␀accompany
him in the voyage,␀the two friends left Calcutta early inyMay, and
on the 14thyof that month, embarked on board the Dover Castle,ywith␀the intention to visit Madras. The first effect of the sea-air was
beneficial toyboth. Respecting his friend, Mr. Corrie observed:--

 e by‚ÄúMr. Brown, since his coming on board is much recovered,
     thoughystill very weak. He has, at times a great deal
 e byof his former wit, andysound sense in conversation.
 e byHe observed, that he had generally found considerable
 e byscrupulosity attended with little understanding, and some
 e bydefect in morality.‚Äù

This record is dated on the 17thyof May: and on the 30th, Mr. Corrie
writes:--

 e by‚ÄúMany events have taken place since writing the above,
 e bywhich I would␀remember. We lay at Saugur till the 23rd.
 e byduring that time I was much occupied about Mr. B. and
 e bycabins, &c. I had time, however, to get near some of

 e byheaving the anchor, &c., we could␀not have worship. I␀␀␀␀␀␀␀employed myself most of the morning in reading Paley‚Äôs
     Sermons. Mr. B. was too ill to attend to any thing; about␀␀␀␀␀␀2 o‚Äôclock on that day, as Mr. B. and I were talking, we
 e byperceived the ship to touch ground; and, after two or three

 e byalarmed on deck; the masts were ready to go over-board,

 e bywater, but obliged to anchor, the ship being unmanageable:
 e byshe was found to leak, and all␀hands ordered to the pumps:

 e byLord, let him do as seemeth him good;‚Äù then quietly putting

 e byI would␀return to Thee,␀do thou quicken me, as thou art␀␀␀␀␀␀wont! I found the evening prayers in church very grateful

Fatigue and exposure to the weather, added to the want of sustenance
proper for an invalid, so worked upon the exhausted frame of Mr.
Brown, that notwithstanding all that medical skill and the attention
of friends could␀do for him, he closed his mortal career within
about a fortnight of his return to Calcutta. As regarded Mr. Corrie,
his health still required that he should␀try the efficacy of a
sea-voyage, and therefore he made arrangements for embarking for the
Isle of France, at the beginning of July. In the meanwhile, however,
he was occupiedyin various clerical duties, and paid the last tribute
of affection to his deceased friend, Mr. Brown, by a funeral sermon
preached in the Presidency church. With reference to this and the
circumstances connected with his intended voyage, Mr. C.yremarks:--

  e b‚ÄúDiamond Harbour, ship Bengal, merchantman, July 5, 1812.

 e byoccurred, and how little,yalas, improved!

  e b‚ÄúOn the fourteenth of June, Mr. B. departed this life.
 e byI have learned, from this event, the absolute necessity

 e byI may inherit the promises. I have had frequent public

 e byeffect of removing prejudice from the minds of some; the
 e byenmity of ---- is too apparent, but heycan goyno further␀␀␀␀␀␀than permitted. OyLord, look in mercy on the congregation

  e b‚ÄúJuly 12th. I have been detained here beyond my
     expectations; my mind generally atypeace through Jesus

Whilst detained on the shoresyof India, Mr. Corrie received a letter

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   ‚ÄúJuly 20, 1812.

  e b‚ÄúA letter of your‚Äôs without date, reached me yesterday, and

 e byyour continuance in thisy‚Äòvale of tears:‚Äò--fears for myself

 e bymoreyeffectually by simple dependence on the promised

 e byabilities, and promisesygreat usefulness. Of the Baptists,

     where some, in most months, are added to them. They have
 e bysome brethren at Agra; some at Dinapore, or Patna (which
 e byare close together,) but I hear of none persuaded by
     them except a young officer, who was awakened by some
     means at a distance from Christian society, and having
 e bynone that he could␀advise with, wrote to them; and from
 e byone step to another seems now disposed to join them. He

     and Sanscrit are valuable, because they have proper helps;
  e bbut their other productions areyinferior. Of those who
  e bhave joined them in Calcutta, it is no disparaging of

  e binferior rank. I hesitateynot to say, they prevailyby legal
 e byconsiderations for the most part; and I lament that their␀␀␀␀␀␀prejudices against the Church of England will not suffer
     them toytake one step beyond their own narrow enclosure.
     But may the work of the Lord, as far as it is His work,
  e bprosper in their hands, no less than in ours: and may we
 e byallybe found one in Christ Jesus! For myself, I write this
 e byon board of ship in Saugur roads, at the entrance of the
     river leading to Calcutta. I amygoing to sea on account of
 e bya liver-complaint, which has afflicted meynow upwards of
     threeyyears, and does not give way to medicine. I amytold,
     it has not yet injured my constitution, but ministerial
 e bylabours completely counteract the effects of medicine, so
  e bthat I can only hope for a cure from rest and change of
 e byair. Iyfeel it a duty to try these; and for this purpose
  e bcame down from Cawnpore.‚Äù

Scarcely had Mr. Corrie put to sea, when he again had to encounter
␀␀␀␀perils of the deep. Writing on the 31st July, he remarks:--

  e b‚ÄúOn the 27th it began to blow a gale, which continued the
     whole day with great violence: and though its violence
 e byabated in the evening, it has been blowing weather ever
 e bysince. Yesterday, we were obliged to heave overboard
  e b370 bags of rice, it having got damaged from the water
  e bwe shipped continually, and gave the ship soygreat a
 e bylurch that we were afraid she would␀sink, the pumps not
     being able to keep her clear. On Monday especially, our␀␀␀␀␀␀danger was apparent, and my mind was at first a good deal
 e bydiscomposed. I retired to my cabin, and on ayreview could
 e bysay that I have not wasted my health in self-pleasing, that
 e byhowever mixed my services have been with sinful motives,
  e byet the furtherance of the gospel has been my chief aim,
     and now I amyhere seeking renewal of strength, much against
     my own inclination; but at the urgent importunities of
     friends: and if it please God to restore me, I intend no
 e byother work or way but to serve Him in the gospel of his␀␀␀␀␀␀Son. Such reflections encouraged me to draw near with
  e bfaith to God in Christ. I was favoured with freedom of
 e byaccess, and by prayer and thanksgiving, was enabled to
  e b‚Äòcast my burden on the Lord,‚Äô and to hope for and expect
     the preservation afforded. I, at the same time, devoted
     my body, soul, and spirit anew to the service of God my␀␀␀␀␀␀Saviour; and I do now renew that dedication, and purpose
  e bthrough thy strength, O blessed␀Saviour, to know nothing,

  e bJesus Christ, and the diffusion of his blessed␀truth.

  e b‚ÄúAugust 3rd. The wind still boisterous, and often stormy;
  e bthis destroys our comfort with the poor attendance we have
 e byon board.bI endeavour to improve my mind by reading and
  e bconversation with ----, who seems to come more and more

 e byDuring yesterday and to-day we have been returning to
  e bnearly our former way; the wish of putting into some port

  e bthine appointments! I know not what is best: thou, Lord

 e bythat effect: because others apprehend no danger, I amyready

Owing to this stormy weather, contrary winds, and a strong current,
␀␀␀␀ship made but little way, for after a fortnight‚Äôsysailing,
Mr. Corrie found himself no further on his voyage than the Cacoas
islands. The captain then decided to retrace their course somewhat,
with a view to getting to the westward, and that object was
accomplished so far that toward the end of August, the ship was
slowly working her way down the coast, and on the 6th of September
entered the Vizagapatamyroads. It appears however, from Mr. Corrie‚Äôs
Journal, that the prospect of a long and tedious voyage, and the
consequent uncertainty as to the time when he might get back again
to India, often ‚Äòfilled his mind with painful anxiety.‚Äô The return,
too, of former pains in his side, he regarded as being chiefly␀occasioned by ‚Äòthe want of regular food and exercise.‚Äô These and
other considerations weighed so powerfully on his mind that for
some time previously to coming within sight of the coast of India,
he had decided to abandon the voyage to the Isle of France, and to
‚Äòdisembark at whatever port t␀␀␀ship might put in.‚Äô On reaching
Vizagapatamyhe carried that purpose into effect. This place had
then been occupied for about eight years as a central station by␀the London Missionary Society; and was, moreover, a place of much
interest to Mr. Corrie, as being the scene of the labours and death
of Mr. Desgranges, who is so feelingly mentioned in the foregoing
letter to Mr. Buckworth. Here, therefore, Mr. Corrie remained for
more than a fortnight in the house of Mr. Pritchett, the London
Society‚Äôsymissionary.yDuring his stay at Vizagapatam, Mr. C. notes on

  e b‚ÄúSeptember 20th. This day six years I arrived in Calcutta:
 e byI scarcely know what to say or think of the time gone by.yI

  e bfavour shown me here is very humiliating, being so much

  e b‚ÄúSeptember 23rd. On board ␀␀␀␀ship Union, leaving

  e b‚ÄúThough the missionaries are doubtless good men, yet I

The following are also extracts from Mr. C‚ÄôsyJournal:--

On the evening ofyThursday the 8th October 1812, Mr. Corrie reached
Calcutta, and on finding that Mr. Thomason was laid aside from duty,
by an attack of illness, Mr. C. undertook the services at the Old
Church for a few weeks, until his friend should be convalescent.
It was not his desire, however, to remain long absent from his own
station, now that his health had been in a great measure restored
to him, and he, therefore, made preparations for proceeding to
Agra. But before leaving Calcutta, Mr. C. was united in marriage to
Elizabeth, the only child of Mr. W. Myers,ya gentleman whose name
has already occurred in these memoirs as among the friends of the
Rev.yD. Brown. Respecting Miss Myers,ythe observation of Mr. Thomason
was, in reference tobher marriage with Mr. Corrie, that she was
‚Äòone who entered into all his missionary views,band was indeed a
help-meet for him.‚Äô It was now, also, that the Christian friendship
which subsistedbthroughout after-life between Mr. Corrie and Abdool
Messeeh, may be said to have commenced; for the sincerity of Abdool‚Äôs
profession of the gospel having by this time been well proved, it was
decided that he should accompany Mr. Corrie to Agra, as a Scripture
Reader and Catechist. An outline of the history of this remarkable
convert to the Christian faith, was drawn up at the time by Mr.
Corrie,[84] and has been frequently␀reprinted; so that it would be
superfluous, in this place, to do more than tobsupply such a brief
sketch of Abdool‚Äôs earlier life, as may serve for the elucidation
of some particulars respecting him, which are given below. It will
be remembered, then, that Abdool was a native of Delhi; but that
when arrived at man‚Äôs estate he accompanied his family to Lucknow;
being all the while a zealous Mahomedan. From thence he removed
to Cawnpore, where he was so impressed by the preaching of Mr.
Martyn, that he became a candidate for baptism, accompanied Mr. M.
to Calcutta, and was, after due probation, admitted into the church
of Christ, by Mr. Brown, on Whit-Sunday, 1811. From that time until
he joined Mr. Corrie‚Äôs family, Abdool lived in Calcutta or the
neighbourhood, suffering much opposition from the Mahomedans, but
being the instrument of much good to many of his countrymen.

At the latter end of November 1812, Mr. and Mrs. Corrie took leave
of Calcutta for Agra, Abdool with several Christian native children
occupying a boat by themselves. Abdool employed himself during the
journey in teaching the children to read, &c., and in composing hymns
to native measures. These he was in the habit of singing with the
children and servants when the party came to anchor for the night. As
also, the journey from Calcutta occupied many weeks, it was customary
to remain at anchor throughout everybSunday that occurred on the way;
and on those occasions Abdool used to collect together the boatmen
and others on the banks of the river, and explain the scriptures
to them. On many occasions, too, he maintained arguments with
Brahmins and Romanists on subjects connected with their respective
superstitions; but, as copious accounts of those disputes are given
in the printed journal of Abdool‚Äôs proceedings, it is not considered
necessary to repeat them. The result usually was to call forth much
hostility to Abdool,yand to expose him to personal danger. Thus, from
Cawnpore, 17th Feb. 1813, Mr. Corrie writes to his brother-in-law:--


 e by  e by  e by  e by TO J. W. SHERER, ESQ.

   e ‚ÄòWe expect to leave this about the 25th; we should have
  e bgone before now, but that Abdool Messeeh is gone to
   e Lucknow to visit his family,band will not return until
  e bthe 24th. I was not for his going, nor did he intend to
   e go, but on his writing from Allahabad, a brother and
  e bnephew of his came over here, and received him with
   e much affection, and told him, that his father, mother,
  e banother brother and three sisters, with their children,
 e byhad determined on coming over, if he would not go to see
  e bthem; professing also, that all his family wish to become
  e bChristians together with him. There has been a great stir
  e bat Lucknow about his conversion. A crowd assembled one
  e bnight about his father‚Äôs house and demanded that he should
 e byopenly renounce Abdool,yor they should suspect him also of
  e bbecoming a Christian. He and the brothers said, they would
 e bynot renounce Abdool,ywho had always behaved kindly,band now
 e bywrote to them with great affection. A tumult ensued, which
 e byrequired the interference of the Cutwal; and the report
 e bywas carried to the Nabob‚Äôs son, if not to the Nabob. The
  e bgreat men took the part of Abdool‚Äôs family,band reproved
  e bthe others; but under these circumstances, I did not think
 e byit advisable for Abdool to go over, nor would he but for
  e bthe desire manifested by his family to cleave to him. This
   e made him determined to run all risks, and also because his
 e bysisters‚Äô husbands threatened to forsake them, if they came
 e byover here; and Abdool argued it was not right for him to be
  e bthe cause of their disobeying their husbands, so he would
  e bgo to them. Indeed his whole conduct manifests a great deal
 e byof discretion and good sense, though nobsuperiority in
 e byunderstanding; so that I fear nothing from indiscretion,
  e band have sent a servant of my own with him,band hope the
   e Lord will be his defence.

In a letter, however, which Mr. Corrie addressed soon after this to
Lieutenant (now Captain) Peevor of H. M. 17th foot, he states that
Abdool ‚Äúwas obliged to retreat privately,‚Äù from Lucknow, the rage of
the Mahomedans was so great against him. Yet it appears that ‚Äúhis
father, mother, two brothers and two nephews, had all professed their
readiness to embrace the gospel,‚Äù and that the nephews returned with
Abdool to Cawnpore.

Mr. Corrie and his party reached Agra on the 18th of April 1813.
There he was made acquainted with the death of Mr. Martyn. In a
letter to Mr. Sherer,band with reference to that event, Mr. C.
writes:--

   e ‚ÄúWe arrived here in good health, and found your letter
 e bycontaining the affecting intelligence of Martyn‚Äôs
 e bydeath:--to us afflictive, to him happy beyond expression.
  e bI thought of writing immediately, but could find nothing
  e bbeyond lamentations to express; lamentations for us, not
 e byfor him. He was meet for the ‚Äúinheritance of the saints
 e byin light,‚Äù--my master is taken away from me, O for a
 e bydouble portion of his spirit! The work of printing and
  e bdistributing the scriptures, will henceforth go on more
  e bslowly. It is impossible to have so lively an impression of
  e bthe importance of supplying the written word,ywhere people
  e bhave not intercourse with the spiritu␀␀␀␀␀needy. You all
 e byfeel for the poor English, because you now and then talk
 e bywith them,band have demonstration of their ignorance on
 e byeternal things. Thus those who enter among the heathen have
  e ba demonstration on the subject, which constrains them to
  e bpity them,band to exclaim, ‚ÄòO that theyyhad but a Bible!‚Äô‚Äù

Shortly after his arrival at Agra, Mr. Corrie enquired for,band
obtained a house, every way suitable for the residence of Abdool
Messeeh. The rentywas agreed upon, and possession in part given, but
in the meantime Abdool‚Äôs circumstances becoming known, the owner of
the house, a Mahomedan, departed from his agreement, and would not
accept Abdool for a tenant. But shortly afterwards a property called
Boottats Kuttra, a court in the middle of the principal street in
Agra, being put up for sale, it was bought by an English gentleman,
who generously gave it for the purposes of the mission. In this place
Abdool Messeeh regularly conducted Divine Service twice on Sundays,
and once, sometimes twice, during the week. He had family worship
also, daily with the Native Christians,ywho resided in or near the
Kuttra. Some account of these missionary proceedings is given by Mr.
C. in answer to a letter from Mr. Sherer. He writes, on the 8th June
1813:--

   e ‚ÄúThe plan of a Native Free-School I admire greatly; and
  e bhave no doubt of its utilityband success. I have been
  e bproceeding on that plan ever since I came to the country.
  e bJames[85] failed me, and one of the boys, (Simon) through
  e bthe wickedness of his parents, is likely to fail me also;
   e yet Iydo not despair. Osman is one of the cleverest of any,
  e bin English; Nicholas, most solid; Abdool‚Äôs two nephews are
  e bpromising, especi␀␀␀␀␀the younger, Shumsher Rham. We have
  e ba tribe of younger ones,band a whole host of little sons
 e byof drummers. J. A. is coming, on the first opportunity, to
   e be my English master for them; which will relieve me much,
  e bboth as to time and labour; after two disappointments,
  e band many attempts, we have at length obtained an old
  e bpremise in the city. This is the fourth day we have been
  e bin possession;band a school is already collected there.
  e bThe whole city rings with this, to them newydoctrine; and
  e bcopies of the NewyTestament are eagerly sought for: not
 e bya tongue moves in opposition; which is a matterbboth of
  e bsurprise, and congratulation. Abdool Messeeh is greatly
 e bycalled forth; and his heart becomes more and more in the
 e bywork,bas people come forward. Two or three, indeed many,
  e bhave professed their wish to be baptized; but perhaps these
  e bare not the most hopeful, for being most forward. The
  e bsubject has now got amongst the English; and they evidently
 e bydon‚Äôt know what to make of it.... The people in the city
  e bgenera␀␀␀␀speak of the school with great approbation, and
  e bhope it will be made a college. The establishmentyfor the
 e bywhole is now, a Molwee 20 Rs.; an Ostad 10 Rs.; a writer 7
 e byRs.; and a schoolmaster for the little boys 8 Rs.; besides
   e Durwan 3yRs.; and about 25 Rs. for the maintenance of
 e bychildren, &c. &c. So that,bI fear, I cannot enlarge much
 e byourbpresentyestablishment.‚Äù

Although it had hitherto been the unchristian policy of the Indian
government either to discountenance all efforts to raise the moral
and religious condition of their subjects, or to leave them to be
altogether dependent for instruction in the great truths of revealed
religion, on the personal zeal and narrow resources of a fewyprivate
individu␀␀s, yet a better state of things appeared now to be at
hand. The various missionary societies,band the religious portion of
Britain at large, regarded the renewal of the company‚Äôs charter to
be a favourable opportunity for pressing upon the attention of the
legislature, the destitute condition of India with respect to the
gospel. This was accordinglyydone,band the resultywas, that during
the month of June 1813, the parliament affirmed the necessity for a
Church establishmentyin India; voted that itywas the duty of England
tobpromote the moral and religious improvement of her subjects
in India; and that facilities ought likewise to be afforded to
persons desirous of going to India for the purpose of accomplishing
those benevolent designs. This favourable change in the policy of
government was of course unknown to Mr. Corrie, when he addressed the
following letter:


   e     e     e     e TO THE REV. MR. SIMEON.

  e bdesirableness of some extension of ourbpresent

  e bamong us cry shame on the want of attention of our
  e bgovernors to this point. If we had a sufficient

  e bMartyn? It seems almost as if Mr. Carey‚Äôs prophecy were
  e bcoming true, that Godywould not employ _us_ in the work
 e byof evangelization. Amidst the great attention we hear of,

  e bnow Mr. Brown and Mr. Martyn no longer bring these subjects

 e byis admired as abcomposition, no less than as containing

The success which, under the divine blessing, had so signally

  e b‚ÄúI was far from expecting anyyseparate contribution to the

  e bensure edification,band that the workbshouldynotbfailyin
  e bafter-generations.‚Äù

Early in January 1814, Mr. Corrie left Agra on a visit to Delhi;
and was there met by some natives from Meerut, who were desirous of
baptism. One of these was a Moonshee, in the service of Dr. R., and
who, from conversation with Abdool Messeeh, and the reading of the
translated Scriptures, had been convinced that ‚ÄòJesus is the Son of
God.‚Äô Another was a Molwee, abnative of Rampoor, who had, in like␀manner, been led to expect salvation only through Christ. A third was
an aged Birajee, who possessed great influence among thebnatives, but
whose faith in the Hindoo and Mahomedan systems had been completely
shakenbby the deistical writings of Cuber, a satirical poet, who
lived at Benares. This Birajee had made many enquiriesyrespecting the
Christian religion, and once thought of joining thebRomish sect,
but was deterred from doing so by finding that they used images in
their worship. He had ultimately been brought to a knowledge of ‚Äúthe
truth as it is in Jesus,‚Äù by the perusal of thebNew Testament, a
copybof which, in the Nagree, he had lately obtained. For the sake,
therefore,bof these and other natives, Mr. Corrie determined on a
visit to Meerut. Therebhe had the satisfaction to find abcongregation
of from twenty to␀thirty Christians, under the direction of Mr.
Bowley,[90] assistedbby the Hukeem from Agra; and after due enquiry
and examination,bhe baptized the Rampoor Molwee and the Birajee,
on Sunday, January 30. On the following day Mr. C. baptized alsoba
native woman, and returned to Agra early in February.

It may here be mentioned, that the success with which it pleased
God to markbthe labours of Mr. Corrie and his friends at Agra, made
that city a place toward which those, notbunnaturally, looked for
assistance, who were anxious for the spread of the gospelyamong the
tribes of NorthernbIndia. Mr. C. was therefore,bfrequently requested
to supply,bfrom among thebconverts at Agra, scripture-readers, to
be employed at other stations. In answer to anbapplication of that
nature, he writes--


   e     e     e     e    TO CAPTAIN PEEVOR.

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e‚ÄúFeb. 3. 1814.

  e b‚ÄúI have been thinking who I could send you as a reader; but
   e really fear that none of thosebatbpresent with me, are fit
  e bfor the appointment. Itbrequires some time to make them
  e bacquainted with the Scriptures; and some time for them to
  e blayyaside the oldyways of thinking, in which they have been
  e bbrought up: so that only one, like yourself, who wouldybear
  e bwith them, rather than expect them to bend in all things
  e bto you, could be intrusted with the care of a very recent
  e bconvert. Abdool Messeeh‚Äôs nephew is, next to his uncle, the
  e bmost deeply humbled of the new converts; and him his uncle
  e bdoes notbwish to part with,batbpresent. I will,bhowever,
   e when we reach home, write to you further on the subject;
  e bfor you must know we left Agra on the 10th of January, and
  e bhave been at Delhi and Meerut.‚Äù

Yet the quickbsuccession in which first one native and then another
had been added to the church at Agra and elsewhere, was so unusual
a phenomenon in India,bthat some of the friends of missions seem to
have been apprehensive, lest converts shouldyhave been admitted to
baptism, before the sincerity of their faith and repentance had been
sufficiently tested. On that point, therefore,bMr. Corrie writes in
answer


   e     e     e     eTO THE REV. MR. THOMASON.

  e b‚ÄúMany kind and cordial thanks for your cautions respecting
  e bbaptism. I have in no instance administered [that
  e bsacrament] but where there seemed experience, as well
  e bas knowledge, of the grace of God. Even the youths seem
  e bconvinced of sin, and aware of the necessitybof avoiding
  e bit. But the further we advance, the more arduous does my
   e post become. Nothing has occurred to make me doubt the
  e bsincerity of any of thebbaptized,--but others have tried to
  e bdeceive. Ibwish all thebconverts could remain with me; but
   e it is no sin in them that they cannot live without food;
  e band I cannot maintain them all.‚Äù

Mr. Corrie then adds, on the subject of scripture readers:--

    e‚ÄúThe Hukeem discovers great reluctance to leave, but at the
  e brequest ␀␀␀S. for abnative Christian, he goes on Thursday
   e next, and Abdool Messeeh goes with him on a visit. He will
  e bbe in as goodyhands as here: his son is likely to␀prove
  e ba treasure. He is quite familiar with the Arabic of the
   e Koran, is very quickbof comprehension, needs seldom to have
  e ba lesson repeated, and is devoted to study. His frame of
  e bbody is but weakly; and thus devotedness to learning is
  e baccompanied (as is generally the case) with less appearance
   e of zeal for others. How few, like Martyn,blive only that
  e bthey may impart knowledge! This youth appears a sincere
  e bconvert. He and two others are, henceforth, to have a
  e blesson daily in Hebrew. In two months he has learned to
  e bconstrue the English New Testament; and purposes acquiring
  e balsobthe rudiments of Greek.‚Äù

The following extracts from letters written about this time, afford

   e     e     e     e  TO J. W. SHERER, ESQ.

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   ‚ÄúAgra, March 4, 1814.

  e b‚ÄúI have little to write to you about, except what is
  e bconnected with the affairs of our Church here. The number
  e bof converts and present inquirers on all hands, renders
  e battention to our concerns necessary that ‚Äòthe workbshould
   e not fail.‚Äô I do notbwrite down the tenth part of the
   e interesting particulars that come to our ears from Delhi,

  e bconsidered in respect of individuals, comprehends but a
   e very insignificant part of the population, yet shews, I
  e bthink,bthat ‚Äúthe report is gone forth,‚Äù and enquiry begins
  e bto be made. Labourers also, are, I trust, springing up,
   e qualified for the workbof instruction.... The Rampoor
  e bMolwee seems very disinterested; and is by far the most
  e bclever man we have yet had. The Moonshee, whobaccompanied
  e bhim, is notbvery superior, but appears sincerely disposed

  e bgotba copy of thebgospels. Praised be God, nothing actually

  e bcomplaints and requests.‚Äù


  e b   e b   e b   e b   TO CAPTAIN PEEVOR.

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b  ‚ÄúAgra, March 20, 1814.

  e b‚ÄúI have by no means been forgetful of your wishes
  e brespecting a reader, but have not yet been able to
  e bdetermine anything for you. The success attending the word
  e bis very gratifying and encouraging; but it requires time
  e bto acquire information sufficient to become a teacher of
  e bothers; so that I hesitate even to wish the new converts

   e triumph. ‚ÄòThere are your converts!‚Äô would be the cry. ‚ÄòSo
  e bwould we have it!‚Äô But be assured, it is as much my wish as
   e it can be your‚Äôs, to send the light of the gospel to you as
  e bfast as possible.

  e b‚ÄúI do notbknow that our plan of schooling is by any means
  e bthe most advantageous. It is simply this:--Before nine
   e o‚Äôclock,bthe children learn by heart, catechism or grammar,
   e in the way of question and answer. After that Persian; and
  e bafter mid-day, English. This school consists of Christian

  e band so entirely negligent of time, at the same time so
  e bignorant of the advantages of regularity, and improvement

  e bsubject. In this workbI am oftenbreminded of that passage,
   e ‚ÄòYe have need of patience, that having done the will of
  e bGod, ye may receive the promises.‚Äô May we be followers
  e bof them, who, through faith and _patience_, inherit
  e bthe promises! Faith we acknowledge [to be]ba heavenly
   e principle, but oftenblook for patience in ourselves; which,
  e balas, is no more of ourselves than faith.‚Äù

Within a short time of the date of this letter to Captain Peevor, the
fall of two of the baptized from ‚Äútheir stedfastness,‚Äù occasioned Mr.
Corrie some distress,balthough his knowledge of the native character
had prepared him, as has been seen, to expect that offences would
sooner or later come. As regarded his own experience, however, all
outward trials and perplexities only seem to have led him to depend
more simply on the divine aid. Thus on the 10th of April 1814,
(Easter-day) Mr. C. writes:--

 b   ‚ÄúTo-day I have completed my 37th year. An eventful year
  e bthe last has been, from the spiritual enlargement of the
   e Church, both among white and black. Many trials, too,
  e bhave sprung up from the same cause; and oftenbI am at
  e bmy wits‚Äô end. I find all creatures, in themselves, but
  e bmiserable comforters; and I have, at times, a deep, deep
  e bfeeling of the disorder andbmisery introduced by sin; of
  e bthe strange perverseness and blindness of my own nature in
  e bparticular, and of human nature in general. My own folly
  e band perverseness appears, in the preference of outward
  e blabour and bodily exercise to spiritual obedience, and
  e bmental discipline. Yet, at times, Ibhave stronger views
  e bthanbI ever had before, of the excellence of the Divine
  e bnature, and the blessedness of knowing, and being with God.
   e I trust my heart is notbweary of this work, though often
  e bgroaning in it. God has raised pecuniary help, but the
  e bresponsibility attachedbto it makes me sometimes wish to
  e bdecline it. Mr. B. is coming to help in this work, which I
  e bshould rejoice in: and the Molwee, from Rampoor, promises
  e bto be a ‚Äòburning and a shining light.‚Äô Mybdear wifebgrows
   e in union of heart and labour with me; and, on the whole, I
  e bhave nothing to regret but my own hardness of heart, whilst
   e I would set up an ‚ÄòEbenezer‚Äô to my covenant God! Amen.‚Äù

Itbwas at this time that Mr. Corrie, at the suggestion of Mr.
Thomason, addressed a letter to the committee of the Church
Missionary Society in Calcutta, on the subject of missionary
schoolmasters. In that communication he observed:--

 b       e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b  ‚ÄúAgra, April 6, 1814.

  e b‚ÄúThe circumstance lately come to our knowledge respecting
  e bthe provisions in the Honourable Company‚Äôs new charter,
   e for affording religious instruction to our fellowbsubjects
   e in this country, leads me to submit the following
  e bconsiderations to your notice, to be forwarded [to
  e bEngland,] if you approve, for the consideration of the
   e Church Missionary Society.

  e b‚ÄúThe state of those descendants of Europeans, and others
  e bprofessing Christianity, at the different European
  e bstations, has always appearedbto me worthy of attention,
  e bboth as it respects themselves, and asba medium through
   e which the natives in general might be approached, with
  e bthe greatest success. There are many persons of the above
  e bdescription at Berhampore, Monghyr, Bagulpore, Patna,
   e Dinapore, Buxar, Benares, Chunar, Allahabad, Cawnpore,
   e Agra, Delhi, Meerut, and other inferior stations.

 b   ‚ÄúAt each of these places, a schoolmaster might be placed
   e with great advantage. His ostensible, and indeed first
   e duty, should be to educate Christian children, and to
  e bconduct public worship for native christians. The Divine
  e bblessing would, doubtless, attend the education of these
  e bchildren; and some of them would be led to choose the work
  e bof instruction; and would go forth among the natives, with
  e btenfold advantage over any European missionary. As these
  e bpeople are in general very poor, the schoolmaster must
   e be supplied with a maintenance, and, together with the
   e christian children, should give instruction inbEnglish
  e bto as many children as he could attend to. The Native
   e christian children might learn the principles of religion
   e in Hindoostanee; and be farther instructed in the language
  e bof the country, bybmeans of native instructors, under the
   e superintendance of the European master; whilst the latter
   e would instruct them inbEnglish, and thus open to them the
   e stores of European learning. Many of the natives would
  e brejoice in an opportunity of having their children taught
  e bEnglish, _gratis_; and the necessary intercourse with a
  e bschoolmaster, for this purpose,btends greatly tobremove
  e bprejudice, and to prepare the mind for the reception
  e bof Divine truth. At each of the above stations, abway
  e bappears to be prepared for the propagation of the gospel;
  e band a soil made ready, as it were, to receive the seed of
  e bchristian instruction, the fruits of which would spread
  e bthrough the land.

  e b‚ÄúThe modes of instruction used by our Church are, also,
   e exactly suitedbto the state of thebpeople professing
   e christianity at these places; and they are usually as
  e banxious for the prayer-book, (translated) as for the New
  e bTestament. If our Society could but supply labourers for
   e this field, doubtless, on a properbrepresentation of the
   e subject, government would readily permit them to proceed
  e bhither.

  e b‚ÄúTheir Christian subjects have a claim upon government for
   e such permission, to say the least: and in this way, part
  e bof their subjects would become attachedb[to them] no less
   e from duty, than from interest. The professedly Christian
  e bpart of the natives, are as little attachedbto us as any
  e bother; a sincere lover of his country cannot but wish that
   e this portion of the population, at least, should be brought
  e bto feel common interest with us. Our civil Institutions
  e bhave furnishedbmuch new information to the natives, on the
   e subject of moral right and wrong; and from the increase of
  e brespectability, of late years, in the Honourable Company‚Äôs
  e bservants, as well as from the growth of real piety among
  e bthem,bmuch religious knowledge is gone abroad; addbto this,
   e also, the considerable distribution of translations of the
 b   Scriptures, in various languages, of late years. From all
   e this, an attentive observer cannot but conclude, that as
  e bthe subject of civil liberty becomes better understood by
  e bthe natives, more political danger is to be apprehended
   e from this quarter; unless it be counteracted by those
   e motives to contentment, and obedience to the ‚Äúpowers
  e bthat be,‚Äù which the gospel alone supplies, than from any
  e btemperate attempts at evangelization. Of these attempts,
  e bthe plan of schoolmasters, such as our society could
  e bapprove at the different stations, as above suggested,
  e bseems to me the least objectionable, and to imply no cause
  e bof irritation whatever in the natives. Whilst there is
   e every ground, from reason and Scripture, to expect that the
   e blessing of God would attend endeavours of this kind.‚Äù

As, also, the government of Lord Moira then professed to have in
contemplation some scheme for the education of the natives of
India at large, Mr. Corrie thought it his duty to write to Sir
George Nugent, to request that the Native christians might not be
overlooked. With reference to that important matter he observes in a
letter


  e b   e b   e b   e b TO J. W. SHERER, ESQ.

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b  ‚ÄúApril 21, 1814.

  e b‚ÄúI fear lest the school-plan proposed [bybgovernment]
   e should swallow up all the funds government can spare, in
   e mere literary objects, and the gospel be left still to
  e bdepend on the charity of God‚Äôs people. There is nothing in
   e Arabic or Sanscrit, as atbpresent studied inbIndia, that
   e can enlarge the mind or prepare it for the gospel: so that
   e if Christians also are not to be educated, we shall be just
  e bwhere we were.‚Äù

But whilst Mr. Corrie was thus busily occupied with plans for the
extension and perpetuating of divine truth, his health had again
begun to decline; for in writing to his brother-in-law, he concludes
some observations on the state of religion at Agra, with the
remarks:--

  e b‚ÄúThe care of these thingsbtends greatly tobincrease t␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀inflammation in my side, which is as bad as ever it was at
  e bCawnpore, though I trust it will, as hitherto, give way to
   e medicine.‚Äù

In this expectation, however, Mr. C. was disappointed. His illness
sobincreased upon him,bthat early in July 1814, abvoyage to seabwas
decided upon, as the only means likely tobprolong his life. In the

  e b‚ÄúJuly 31, 1814. Havingbbeen recommended by the medical
   e men to go to England for the recovery of my health,
  e bapplication has been made for leave [to do so.] My mind is,
   e in consequence, much occupied by the subject. Sometimes it
   e is suggested that I am weary of the work, and wish to run
  e baway from the difficulties which the various tempers, and
  e bwants of the people impose upon me. But certain it is that
   e my frame is so shattered that these difficulties agitate me
   e more than can be conceived, and so as tobprevent my gaining
   e strength. On the other hand, I think the horror I feel at
   e the sea-voyage, with the expence and trouble attending it,
   e would prevent my undertaking it from mere self-pleasing
   e motives. I feel, at the same time, so little ability to
  e bbenefit the cause of missions at home, that Ibsee no good,
   e in that view, likely tobarise from the journey. Only a wish
  e bto recover strength to serve God in newness of life, I
   e think, is uppermost, though many base and foolish thoughts␀␀␀␀␀␀␀intrude themselves.‚Äù

Before, however, taking his departure from Agra, Mr. Corrie
administered the Lord‚Äôs Supper to fifty-nine native communicants, and
on the next day (Aug. 18th.) he committed the congregation to the
care of Mr. Bowley and Abdool Messeeh, ‚Äúamid many tears on the part
of the new converts, and much sorrow on his own.‚Äù Respecting that
season of interest and solemnity, Mr. C. writes:--

  e b‚ÄúThe will of the Lord is to be acknowledged inbmy
  e bdeparture, no less than in my arrival at this station.
  e bDuring thebpreceding sixteen months, seventy-one natives
  e bhave received baptism,bof whom about fifty are adults;
  e babout half of them Mahomedans, and the other half Hindoos.
  e bOf these, one has been expelled, six have apostatized,
  e bfour are gone to their friends, and are, we hope, holding
  e bfast their profession; and others are occupying different
   e stations, as readers and Catechists: several catechumens
   e remain to be further proved. I would remark,bthat exactly
   e in opposition to the popular opinion among Europeans in
   e India, the more learned converts, and those who hadbbeen
  e bFakeers, caused us the most anxiety and trouble. In this,
   e as in other respects, the Lord‚Äôs ways are not as man‚Äôs
  e bways; and his gospel will make its way in this country, as
  e busual, first among the poor and least regarded of mankind.‚Äù

It remains only to remark,bthat as the preceding pages, in connection
with the published Journal of Abdool Messeeh, make it appear, that
the moral results of Mr. Corrie‚Äôs short residence at Agra were
neither few nor unimportant; so, it is believed, that the following
observations addressed by him,bsoon after leaving Agra, to a friend
desirous of information respecting the natives of India, will shew,
that his labours had not been prompted by a blind or indiscriminating
zeal, but were regulated by the enlightened convictions, and feeling
heart,bof a Christian philosopher.

  e b‚ÄúThe population of India consists of Mahomedans and
  e bHindoos; though the majority of them are Hindoos. The
  e bcommon people of both classes, are much alike in habits,
  e band superstitions. There is little that is social in the
   e general religious worship of either Mahomedans, orbHindoos;␀␀␀␀␀␀except at certain festivals, when they resort in crowds to
   e the place of assembly; and their respectivebprocessions are
  e bcelebrated in much the same noisy and unmeaning manner.

  e b‚ÄúIn different parts of the country there are Durgahs, or
  e btombs of eminent Mahomedans deceased; which are endowed
  e bwith lands, for the support of persons to read the Koran
  e bat them. This is supposed to have a happy effect on the
   e state of the deceased. At these places, an anniversary
   e is generally observed, which is attended as a fair, by
  e bthe people, no less than to make offerings at the shrine.
  e bThere are certain idol temples, also, by making pilgrimages
  e bto which, Hindoos think theybbenefit deceased ancestors,
  e band forward their own future happiness. At these tombs
  e band temples, thebpriests entertain disciples, who are
  e binstructed in their respectivebcreeds.

  e b‚ÄúExcept at such places, the generality of Mahomedans
  e bobserve the times of daily prayer according to their
   e inclination, wherever they happen to be. In large Mahomedan
  e btowns, indeed, a few assemble at the Mosques on Fridays: at
   e Agra, the number, (except on festivals,) wasbusually six.
  e bThe Hindoos, also, make their offerings at the idol-temple,
  e bat the time most convenient to themselves. So that there is
   e no general appearance of religious observances among them,
   e except at the festivals; when the whole country wears
   e the appearance of a mountebank-show. On these occasions,
  e ba portion of time is given to hear the history of the
  e bprophet,bor god, connectedbwith the occasion; and rich␀␀␀␀␀␀individuals unite to pay a pundit,bor learned Hindoo, who
   e reads to them, usually in the evening, portions of their
  e bbooks, in a chaunting tone of voice, and explains sentence
  e bby sentence, to the audience, as he goes on. By such means
   e the Mahomedans, especially the higher classes of them, are
  e bacquaintedbwith the principal names in the Old and New
  e bTestaments, and with some particulars of their history;
  e bwith the exceedingly gross intermixtures which are to be
  e bfound in the Koran.bThe Hindoo books, also, contain some
   e stories derived from thebbooks of Moses, or from ancient
   e tradition, mixedbwith much fable. These facts, on which all
  e bagree, serve as points on which a Christian may engage them
   e in conversation, and from which by rational deduction, he
  e bmay prove them in error; whilst the Holy Ghost alone can
  e bconvert them to the acknowledgment of the truth.

  e b‚ÄúThe general habits of both Mahomedans and Hindoos greatly
   e assimilate. They alike bathe their bodies, under the
   e idea of rendering themselves more holy in the sight of
   e the Deity; they alike observe the distinction of caste,
  e band avoid eating with certain classes of men; they alike
   e revere Fakeers, or religious mendicants; they alike pay
   e adoration to the rising or setting sun, the new moon, and
  e bto recently-lighted lamps; and they alike implore, in their
  e bprayers, thebintercession of deceased persons, reputed
  e bholy; and observe times and seasons, accountedblucky or
  e bunlucky. They all believe in ghostsband apparitions, and
   e the activebagency of evil spirits. To guard against their
   e influence, they wear charms: and depend on the aid of
   e some particular patron god or saint.bThe more religious␀␀␀␀␀␀enrol themselves as the disciples of some renowned holy
  e bman: and in sickness or under any calamity, or with a view
  e bto obtain some desired object, they multiply charms, or
  e bincrease their offerings,bat the tomb orbtemple: make
  e bvows, orboffer in sacrifice a goat or a fowl, sometimes
  e ba buffalo: and on the day the Mahomedans commemorate
  e bAbraham‚Äôs offering up his son, a camel is sacrificed,
  e bthe flesh of which is eagerly sought after as holy meat.
   e Hence the arguments used bybAbdool Messeeh, respecting
   e the necessity of inward purity.bThe insufficiency of any
  e bmediator, but one that is Divine: the doctrine of the
  e batonement by the sacrifice of Immanuel: the happiness of
   e having an Almighty friend, patron,band protector; and
  e bbeing under the teachingband guidance of the Holy and good
  e bSpirit; were equally applicable to Hindoos and Mahomedans;
  e band his instructions proved equally attractivebto both␀␀␀␀␀␀descriptions of people.... The difficulties in the way of
   e improving every class of native Indians, are greater than
  e bany one can suppose who hasbnot been acquaintedbwith them.
  e bThey are not,bhowever, of a nature to demand great bodily
   e exertion or much severe privation.bThey arise from causes
  e bwhich require a common measure of understanding; and an
  e bintimate acquaintance with human nature, as described in
  e bholy Scripture.

  e b‚ÄúPersons whosebintercourse with the natives relates merely
  e bto temporal concerns, can have little idea of their
  e bpeculiar habits and prejudices. It is thus that I account
  e bfor the very incorrect reports respecting the religious␀␀␀␀␀␀state of the natives of India, and which have been
  e bpublished in England by some who residedbyears among them.
  e bI have even known men of real piety, whosebsituations led
   e them to much intercourse with the natives,bfor mercantile
  e band other temporal purposes, express it as their opinion
   e thatbnothing less than a miraculous interposition could
  e bconvert them to Christianity.bI account for this from
   e the circumstance, that they find such a disposition to
   e chicanery and imposition, in the natives,bas requires the
   e exercise of a degree of authority and even of severity,
   e in men dealing with them, which is unknown in England....
  e bFrom having lived always under an absolute, military
   e despotism, the natives of India, beside thatbnatural
  e bpropensity to selfishness, which in them is uncontrolled,
  e bare cautious how they offend their superiors; and such
   e they consider Europeans of almost every rank. They must
   e have had much proof of the forbearance and gentleness of a
  e bwhite man, before they will ask questions on any subject,
  e bfurther than he appears disposed to answer; and they will
  e bbe cautious how they answer to his questions, lest they
   e should unintentionally offend.... This servile spirit does
  e bnot givebplace entirely, even onbconversion.bIt renders
  e bmuch patience and tenderness necessary in dealing with
  e bnewbconverts,bno less than with the unconverted. They
   e have very little idea of an option being allowed them
   e in things indifferent; and will often appear hesitating
  e band indecisive, when their only fear is offending their
  e bsuperiors. So that the impossibility of benefitting, or
  e bimproving the moral state of the different classes of
   e [native] Christians, is asserted bybmany of the British,
  e bequally with the impossibility of the conversion of the
  e bHeathen.‚Äù


  e b  [85]bThe youth of European descent so often mentioned in
  e b   e b Mr. Corrie‚Äôs correspondence. He acceptedba clerkship
  e b   e b of some kind in the Company‚Äôs service, in preference

  e b  [86] Native judge.

  e b  [87] In a letter addressed about this time to the
  e b   e b correspondents in Calcutta of the Society for

  e b  [88] A native physician.
