  e b     e b     e b     e CHAPTER XII.

  e b     e b     e b     VOYAGE TO ENGLAND.


It was on the 18th of August 1814, that Mr. Corrie left Agra. On
his way to Calcutta he paid visits to his friends at the different
stations on the river, more especially at Chunar and Benares, the
scene of his earliest ministrations in India. Whilst at the latter
place, he received intelligence that Mr. Bowley and Abdool Messeeh␀were so discouraged bybsome difficulties that occurred soon after his
departure from Agra, that both ‚Äúwere ready to desist from the work
of the Lord.‚Äù This occasioned great sorrow and anxiety to Mr. C.,
inasmuch as hebnot only anticipated the breaking up of the native
congregation which he had been mainly instrumental in gathering
around him; but, also, that it might afford matter for triumph to the
enemies of missions. With reference to this subject, Mr. C. observed
in a letter


  e b     e b     e b     e TO MR. SHERER.

  e b‚ÄúIf Abdool should givebup in discouragement, my plans would
  e bbe much set aside. But ‚ÄòJehovah Jireh,‚Äô must be my motto.
  e bThis perplexity brings me often to my knees,band therefore
  e bI hope will work for my good. An expression of Mr. Brown,
   e in our last intercourse, often occurs to me:--‚ÄòInstead of
   e praying always and not fainting, we faint always and never
   e pray, till we find ourselves in a strait.‚Äô‚Äù

On reaching Calcutta, Mr. Corrie found thatball his medical friends
concurred in the opinion that a sea-voyage was absolutely necessary
to eradicate his disorder; but as his wife‚Äôs expected confinement
did not allow of his immediate embarkation, Mr. C. employed himself
during his stay at Calcutta, in setting on foot a school for native
christian schoolmasters. He had an opportunity too, of becoming
acquainted with Bishop Middleton, who had then recently arrived in
India, and of submitting to the consideration of thatbprelate, many
circumstances connected with the state of religion in that country.

On the 1st January 1815, Mr. and Mrs. Corrie went on board the H. C.
ship Europe, with the intention of proceeding, in the first instance,
to the Cape of Good Hope. But on arriving at the Cape, Mr. Corrie
was recommended to proceed to England for the benefit of the colder
climate; and with this advice he considered it his duty to comply.bIn
a letter to Mr. Sherer, dated from Cape Town, March 29, 1815, Mr. C.
relates:--

  e b‚ÄúThis morning I have written to the Adjutant General,
  e benclosing a medical certificate of the necessity for my
   e going on. Our own Surgeon N. an old practitioner here, Dr.
  e bH. and Dr. S. the garrison-surgeon, concur in opinion, and
  e bwithout hesitation on the subject.bI ought,bI believe, to
  e bconsider this as the voice of Providence, and to acquiesce
  e bin it, as I hope I do. But the whole of this dispensation
  e bhas proved the greatest trial I ever met with.bI cannot
   e see my way at all in it; and I go on, driven, as it were,
  e bby circumstances.bI foresee innumerable difficulties
  e bbefore me, without one certainty of good to follow, and
  e butterly despair of profiting myself or others in England.
  e bI am called to walk bybfaith more than ever: sense is all
  e bopposed.‚Äù

Shortly after the date of this letter, Mr. and Mrs. Corrie sailed
from the Cape for England, and after a prosperous voyage, landed at
Southampton on the 22nd June. Here Mr. C. was made acquainted for the
first time, with the publication of the Journal of Abdool Messeeh,
and the interest excited by it. He heard also, with sorrow, of the
death of Dr. Buchanan. On reaching London he was visited bybseveral
of those friends who interested themselves with the progress of the
gospel among the Hindoos; and at an early day attended a meeting of
the Committee of the Society for Missions to Africaband the East, to
communicate to them information on missionary subjects. He was,balso,
invited to attend a Committee of the London Missionary Society, to
answer enquiries respecting their prospects in India. On all these
occasions Mr. C. endeavoured to shew, that from the co-operation of
many pious individuals among the English in India; from the readiness
with which children were sent to school whenever opportunity was
afforded, and from the eagerness with which translations of the
Scriptures were received by many among the natives, there appeared
tobbe fair prospects of good being done among them. He pressed
upon his friends at the same time, the fact, that but little or
nothing had yet been effected in India, for want of a sufficiency
of labourers,band thatbnothing would be done without them; that
wherever missionaries thoroughly acquainted with the language of the
country ␀␀␀␀resided, they found plenty to do, and thatbthough few of
the natives of India in comparison with the multitude, shewed any
concern for religion, still the number of such as did so, exceeded
the opportunities of instruction.

It was a gratifying circumstance to Mr. C. to observe, from the
eagerness with which all persons with whom he conversed, enquired
after the progress of missions among the heathen, thatbthere had
been a great increase of zeal for the spread of divine truth, as
compared with the state of religious feeling at the time he left
England in 1806. He expressed himself, also, agreeably surprised to
find thatbthe increased regard for sacred things which he observed
in London, was not less visible in his native village and county; in
the more orderly observance of the Sabbath, and in the attention that
was given by the gentry and clergy to the education of the poor, to
Sundaybschools, and to the support of different religious societies.
On the other hand his affectionate nature was afflicted by hearing of
the death of neighbours and friends;bby learning that some with whom
he had formerly ‚Äúwalked in the house of God as friends,‚Äù had turned
aside from the simplicity of the gospel; and by ␀␀ving to witness
the many other changes which the lapse of years never fails to bring
about in families and localities. Deep therefore were the emotions
called forth both in preacher and hearers,bwhen, for the first time
after his return from India, Mr. Corrie occupied hisbfather‚Äôs pulpit,
and urged his surviving neighbours to use the numberless changes and
trials and deaths, that had occurred since he last addressed them, as
a reason for increased anxiety to secure to themselves an enduring
inheritance.[91]

No sooner, however, had Mr. C. somewhat recruited his health, than he
visited his friends, in different parts of England; taking occasion
tobplead the cause of missions, both from the pulpit and at public
meetings, as opportunities occurred. Such portions of his time,
also, as were not thus occupied, he devoted to a revision of the
Liturgy in Hindoostanee. His purpose was,bif practicable, to carry
out with him to India, a reprint of that important translation, for
the use of the native Christians.

In the spring of 1816, Mr. Corrie was engaged to preach the
anniversary sermon for the Church Missionary Society in London. With
reference to that circumstance he wrote


  e b   e b   e b   e b TO J. W. SHERER, ESQ.

   e ‚ÄúI am appointed to preach that sermon, which I would
  e bgladly have avoided: but it was said, ‚ÄòThat many would
  e bbe discouraged if I held back; for thatbthe idea would
  e bbe, thatbthe subject [of missions] was not considered so
  e bimportant by us in India, as it has been represented here.‚Äô
  e bI therefore consented, leaving the issue to God.‚Äù

Before preaching the sermon, however, Mr. Corrie availed himself of
Mr. Simeon‚Äôs judgment and experience; and in transmitting a copy of

   e ‚ÄúI am deeply sensible of its defects. Being anxious to
  e bintroduce a number of facts,bnot, as I think, sufficiently
   e known, there is too little Scripture quotation; and I feel
  e bit to be wanting in a devotional spirit,bthough I hope the
  e brelation mayboccasion a feeling of compassion, and excite
  e bto exertion in behalf of the heathen.‚Äù

This hope seems, in some measure, to have been realized, for the
accounts given at the time, state thatbthis sermon, which was

convictions respecting the moral condition and responsibilities of
the heathen, and developes the means which his experience led him
tobregard as best calculated to rescue the Hindoo from debasing
superstitions; a brief abstract of the sermon cannot well be omitted.
Let it be observed, then, thatbMr. Corrie purposed in the first
instance

   e ‚ÄúFairly to meet the objections made against missionary
   e efforts, as if the present state of the heathen were
  e bunavoidable--as if they were scarcely accountable for their
   e errors,--and our solicitude on their behalf were therefore
  e bsuperfluous.‚Äù

To meet objections of this kind, he goes on to trace the origin of
all false religion, and in this, observes that

   e ‚ÄúIntercourse with heathen nations had inclined him to the
  e bopinion, thatbthe original revelation made to our first
   e parents after their fall, is the ground of all the worship
  e boffered up throughout the world. Thatbthe dispensations
  e bof God to Noah and to the Church before him, must have
  e bbeen known to the family of Noah, and would be remembered
  e bby his immediate descendants; and carried by thembinto
  e bthe different countries, whither they were afterwards
  e bscattered. Hence, it was, he apprehended, thatbthe custom
   e proceeded, of offering sacrifices in worship, by the
  e bheathen tribes of every description, as the only means
  e bof pacifying the Evil Spirit; who, according to their
   e apprehension of him, is going about seeking whom he may
  e bdevour.

   e ‚ÄúBut there are many circumstances in the state of the
  e bidolatrous nations of the east, that discover a still later
   e acquaintance with Divine revelation, than the time of Noah.
  e bMany coincidences in the fabulous histories of the Hindoos
  e bwith the writings of the Old and New Testament, indicate
  e bthatbthe forefathers of that race were not altogether
  e bignorant of the subsequent circumstances of the church of
   e God. Their present deplorable ignorance and error, cannot
  e btherefore,bbe said to arise from any appointment of the
  e bAlmighty; but from their wilful neglect of those notices of
  e bhis will with which they were originally favoured. The sins
  e bof the fathers are thus, in an especial manner, visited
  e bupon their children. The neglect of parental instruction,
  e bby a just connection between guilt and punishment,
  e binvolves their posterity in ignorance, which is the
   e parent of superstition, and the fruitful source of their
   e miseries and their crimes. This view of the subject ought,
  e btherefore,bto be kept distinctly in mind; that we may not
  e bcharge God foolishly with being, in any other waybthan
  e bby the instituted order of connection between cause and
  e beffect,bthe author of that blindness of mind, and hardness
  e bof heart, which excludes the heathen from the divine
  e bfavour. The declaration of God,bby the prophet Hosea,
  e brespecting Israel, is true also of the heathen,bthough in a
  e bsubordinate degree: ‚Äò_Thou hast destroyed thyself_.‚Äô

   e ‚ÄúThese observations are in a particular manner applicable
  e bto the idolatrous nations of India. In their present
  e bcircumstances, viewed by the light of revelation, they
   e evidently appear ‚Äòwithout God and without hope in the
  e bworld;‚Äô not only as they are without Christ, but as their
   e own religious views and feelingsbrender thembtotally
   e incapable of enjoying God,bor of participating in the
  e bhappiness of the heavenly state.‚Äù

Then after reciting many of the superstitious practices of the

   e ‚ÄúHow then can we avoid the conclusion, thatbthe religious
   e views and feelingsbeven, of these miserable men, do, in the
  e bvery nature of things, exclude thembfrom the approbation
  e bof God, and incapacitate thembfor the enjoyments of the
  e bheavenly state? It is impossible thatba sinner, going out
   e of this world, in expectation of any thing corresponding
  e bwith earthly honours, amusements or enjoyments, should
   e not be metbby disappointment and shame. It is impossible,
  e bthatba soul utterly ignorant of holy, spiritual, and
  e bintellectual enjoyments, should find any place among
   e ‚Äòthe general assembly and church of the first-born; the
  e binnumerable company of angels, and the spirits of just
   e men made perfect.‚Äô Here,btherefore,bthe christian takes
  e bhis firm stand against all who oppose missionary efforts.
  e bThe heathen,bnot only according to the unerring word of
   e God, but by the evidence of facts, are in a perishing
  e bcondition. Without Christ, they cannot be saved. ‚ÄòHe that
  e bhath the Son, hath life;band he thatbhath not the Son of
   e God, hath not life.‚Äô And myriads of these immortal spirits
   e are passing into eternity, whose state and dispositions
   e prove thembto be utterly alienated from the favour of God,
  e bdestitute of spiritual life, and fatally incapacitated for
  e bthe enjoyments of a better world. For without dispositions
   e suited to the enjoyments of the heavenly state, they could
   e no more comprehend the happiness arising from them, even
  e bif admitted to a participation of heaven, than a brute can
  e benjoy the pleasures of reason. And unless this be kept in
  e bmind, it can scarcelybbe hoped, thatba due measure of zeal
  e bfor the salvation of the heathen will be maintained among
   e us.‚Äù

Mr. Corrie then went on to give his reasonsbfor regarding (1st.)
The distribution of the Scriptures in different heathen languages;
(2nd.) The establishing of Missions;band (3rd.) The education of

tobfurther the rescue of the heathen from their perilous condition;
and he concluded by earnestly exhorting his hearers to do all in

There seems to be no doubt but thatbMr. C.‚Äôs Sermon on this, asbhis
addresses on other occasions, whilst conveying to the religious

   e ‚ÄúI was frequently favoured to witness the lively interest
  e bexpressed, by persons in all ranks of life, with regard to
  e bthe state of the heathen.bThe bare mention of some of the
  e bcruelties and superstitions we daily witness, drewbforth
  e btears of commiseration. The news of a single soul turned

When,btherefore,bafter a residence of nearly two years in England,

It maybbe also here mentioned, thatbalthough the frequent public

On the 14th of April 1817,bMr. Corrie embarked on board the Carnatic,

‚Äúbut how to setbabout attempting their good, it is difficult to say.‚Äù
As regarded himself,bMr. C.badded:--

   e ‚ÄúA solemn, but not a painful feeling, sometimes fills my
    emind on recollecting my father‚Äôs house, and the distant
  e bprospect of again beholding it; but the consideration of
  e bthe ‚Äòhouse not made with hands,‚Äô quiets every anxiety,

  e bthoughts of late,babout the variety of religious divisions

On approaching Madeira he again wrote tobhis father:--

   e ‚ÄúYou will be glad to hear that we have proceeded thus far

In a private memorandum,bMr. C.bremarks:--

   e ‚ÄúMyemind is, I think,bmore resolutely and deliberately

   e ‚ÄúMay 10th. During the past week,bI have had much thought

The Carnatic reached Madras early in August, and remained there for

   e ‚ÄúThere is a growing respect for religion in this place.

The Carnatic sailed from Madras on the 20th of August, and arrived at
Calcutta by the end of that month.

  e b     e b     e b     e CHAPTER XIII.

  e b     e b     e b    RETURN TO CALCUTTA.


Although Mr. Corrie, at the time he landed in India, was one of the

  e b     e b     e b     e    e b      ‚ÄúCalcutta, Sep. 22. 1817.

  e b‚ÄúI find a great progress in public opinion respecting

   e observation.‚Äô‚Äù

On Sunday, 12th of October, Mr. Corrie preached a sermon at the Old
Church in Calcutta, on behalf of the Church Missionary Society.bThis
seems tobhave been the first discourse delivered from the pulpit

This person had come from Bareilly tobCalcutta, and had been for
several months under Christian instruction.bThe account which he gave

kinds of austerities; and having, in the meanwhile, heard much of

New Testament; that he read it, and was led ‚Äúto know and feel that
therebis none other name under heaven, given among men, whereby he
must be saved, but only the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.‚Äù

It was on the evening of Nov. 17, 1817, that Mr. Corrie left Calcutta
for Benares. The following are extracts from his Journal at this
time:--

  e b‚ÄúWe have in company, Abdullah, baptized in England;bFuez
  e bMesseeh, baptized in Calcutta; NoorbMesseeh, baptized
   e at Agra; a Christian Khidmutgar,[100] baptized at the

   e of witnessing two distressing instances of the unfeeling
    econduct of the Hindoos, towards the sick and dying. On

   e if the child werebill? One of them answered, ‚ÄòYes.‚Äô Miss

  e btheir work of death. Farther on, a sick man was laid, with

   e ‚ÄòTake him into some warm place, and he will recover:‚Äô to

  e b‚ÄúSunday 24th. Our Christian congregation consisted of

No sooner had Mr. Corrie arrived at Benares, (Jan. 26. 1818.) than
he projected a missionary establishment in the neighbourhood of
thatblarge and populous city. The following extract from a letter
addressed to the secretary of the Calcutta Committee of the Church
Missionary Society, will explain the objects he had in view:--

  e b‚ÄúThree native Battalions arebusually cantoned here; two
   e are now at the station. I have been taking measures for
  e bthe establishment of a school for thebyounger drummers
   e and fifers, and for thebchildren of native Christians
   e attached to these Corps. I have alreadybtwenty-four
  e bnames of children, whose parents desire that they should
   e become scholars too. We also, on Sunday [Feb. 8th.] began
   e Hindoostanee worship, and about fifteen of the above
    eclass attended.bFor thebschool, I have met with a small
   e bungalow conveniently situated, offered for six hundred
   e rupees. In this bungalow Mr. Adlington could also reside
  e bfor the present. I beg, therefore,bthat the Committee will
    econsider whether they can adopt this bungalow and premises
  e bfor a Missionary residence; or whether they would wish
  e bMr. Adlington to reside altogether in Benares;band that
   e premises should be procured for him there on his return
   e from Agra?[101] Let me repeat, then,bthat at this place
  e bthere are immediate calls on the Society for assistance;
   e and thatbnot merely in the hope of probable benefit, but
   e from the actual wants of professing native Christians;
   e whilst many of the natives,bMahomedan andbHeathen,bare
  e bawakenedbto discern the importance of Christianity, and
    ewill probably be encouraged or discouraged by the readiness
  e bor otherwise which we manifest in meeting these wants of
   e our Christian brethren.‚Äù

Mr. Corrie had the satisfaction to find that the Committee in
Calcutta readily entered into his views, and authorized him to
purchase the premises referred to in the preceding letter.bHe was
thus enabled to open a school, to the support of which many of the
European residents at Benares contributed, by monthly benefactions
and subscriptions.

Early in February Mr. Corrie visited Chunar, his first station in
India, and where the native church was now under thebcare of Mr.
Bowley. It appears from the report he sent to the Calcutta Committee
of the Church Missionary Society, that Mr. C. found the mission at
Chunar in a satisfactory state. Under date of Feb. 9, 1818, he writes:

  e b‚ÄúOn the 5th instant I went to Chunar: it was rather late
  e bin the evening when I arrived, but I found several of the
    econvertedbHindoos waiting to see me. Next morning at seven
   e o‚Äôclock, about eighty of the native Christians attended for
  e bdivine worship.bThey began by singing a hymn,bin the native
  e bmeasures, on the sufferings of Christians.bThe regularity
    ewith which they sung, and the earnestness most of them
  e bmanifested, greatly affected me. Mr. Bowley expounded the
  e bParable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins; and concluded the
  e bservice with prayer. Among other things, he prayed for a
   e blessing on the king, and on his nobles in England, and
    ein India. I mention this not as a proof of Mr. Bowley‚Äôs
   e loyalty, for thatbwas known long before,bbut to shew how
  e bthe labours of such men tend to attach the natives of India
  e bto the British nation, by uniting their most important
  e binterests. At ten o‚Äôclock, about one hundred Europeans
   e attended divine service in English; after which,btwelve
    eof theirbchildren were baptized, and eleven marriages
  e bcelebrated.bAt three p. m., the native congregation again
   e assembled to the number of about ninety adults;bwhen,bafter
   e evening prayer, I endeavoured to explain to them and apply
    ethe second Psalm. It appears that the usual number of
  e bEuropeans who attend Divine service regularly in English,
  e bis about forty, and the usual number of native Christians
   e who attend worship in Hindoostanee,bis about seventy or
   e eighty. The number in both congregations has been gradually
   e and regularly increasing, and testifies of itself to the
    ediligence and exemplary conduct of Mr. Bowley, and of the
    eblessing attending his labours.bThe little I was able,
  e bin my short visit, to see of the state of the people,
  e bimpressed me deeply with the value of his labours.bI knew
  e bthe degradation of both European invalids and their native
  e bwives and families, from three years residence among them,
   e and now to behold so many of them adorning by their lives
  e bthe doctrine of God our Saviour, was to me most gratifying,
   e and will be considered an ample recompencebfor all their
    econtributions, by the supporters of our Society.bThere
    ebeing but one place for both the free-school and the
    econgregation to assemble in,bI could not see the scholars
   e at their tasks.bThree or fourbchildren of parents,bwho
    ecan afford it, pay half a rupee per month; with which,
  e btogether with voluntary contributions of some of the pious
  e bsoldiers, Mr. Bowley has provided wall-shades for evening
  e bservice,band supplies the lights. I,balso,econversed at
   e Chunar with ten Hindoos, who appear to be fully convinced
    eof the truth of Christianity, though not yet prepared to
   e encounter thebconsequences of an open profession [of it].
    eSome of them even join Mr. Bowley occasionally in prayers.
    eOne of them, on being asked, what he considered the great
   e peculiarity of the Christian religion? answered,bThat in
   e every other system of religion, works were made a condition
    eof justification, but that in Christianity, only faith in
   e Christ is required; whilst, wonderful to say, it produced
    emore exemplary holiness than any other system.‚Äù

By a statement which Mr. Corrie put in circulation at Secrole, dated

  e b‚ÄúIt having been found on enquiry, that many children of

Of the above-mentioned boys, eight, it was stated, were orphans, or
thebchildren of parents who were too indigent to maintain them; the
consequence was that they had to be provided with sustenance as well
as education. To the school was also attached a Christian Moonshee,
whose office it was to readbthe Scriptures morning and evening,
to as many Christians as chose to attend; and on Sundays, to read
thebservice of the Church of England, and a previously-prepared
exhortation, (both in Hindoostanee) to the native Christians in the
lines,bof whom about thirty or forty, with theirbchildren, were in
the habit of regularly attending.

The object of this statement was to make the European residents at
Benares acquainted with the missionary operations in progress among
them, and to afford t␀␀␀␀‚Äúan opportunity of contributing to the
support of measures, the beneficial tendency of which they were so
well able to appreciate.‚Äù The result was that the schools at Secrole
received such an increase of patronage,bas to be almost wholly
supported by local contributions.

About the middle of March, Mr. Corrie again visited Chunar. In a

Mr. Corrie hadbthe happiness to find t␀at these anticipations

Encouraging, however, as was thisbimproved state of feeling in favour
of missionary labours, there remained abundant scope for thebexercise
of christian zeal. In a letter, addressed to his brother about this
time, Mr. Corrie writes from Benares:--

  e b‚ÄúIn a neighbouring district (with thebmagistrate of which I
  e bam well acquainted) during the last year, two widows were
  e bburned on an average every month; sixblepersbwere buried
   e alive,bor drowned, by their friends; and not less than
   e onebhundred persons destroyed themselves by drowning, in
   e fits of passion, under the idea that theirbghosts would
  e bhaunt the offending party. Such being the strength of
  e bpassion in them, you will not be surprised that murders
   e are exceedingly frequent: and, what is worst of all, their
   e religion encourages these excesses.... The progress of the
  e bgospel isbslow, but advancing. The unholybrivalry of some
  e bwho differ from us in modes of worshipbis a stumbling-block
  e bto a few; and it grieves me to be often obliged to spend
   e my time and my breath in proving the lawfulness of
  e binfant-baptism, and the propriety of baptism by sprinkling.
    eSatan thus divides,bbut he shall not finally prevail.‚Äù

It was now the will of God to exercise the faithband patience of His
servant, by aeno less severe affliction than the death of an only
son. How great this trial proved to Mr. Corrie, will be seen from his
letter on that occasion--


  e b   e b   e b   e b   e TO MRS. MYERS.

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e    e b   e b   e b   e‚ÄúApril 9, 1818.

  e b‚ÄúOur dearest Grandmama will have heard the melancholy
  e btidings communicated to Mr. Sherer yesterday. I judged it
  e bbest, that, if possible,bthe heavy affliction should not
  e bcome upon you suddenly. Your still bleeding heart will more
  e bseverely feel this arrow of the Almighty, winged no doubt
  e bwith love, but piercing to the very quick. Our lovely boy
  e bwas becoming inexpressibly interesting. He was taken with
   e a severe attack nearly three weeks ago, which yielded to
  e bstrong medicine,bthough he never was after as before, but
  e bseemed mending, when by some means, he caught a severe
  e bcold. The doctoresaysbit was of the nature of Influenza,
   e and many in the house have suffered from it. OneSaturday
   e morning we sent for the doctor; medicines did not produce
  e bthe wished-for effect, and we hadba very restless night
   e on Saturday. OneSunday morning my heart began to sink on
   e his account, and the Lord‚Äôs prayer in Church tried both my
  e bprinciples and my feelings.

  e b‚ÄúThroughout Sunday, little alteration appeared;bbut he
   e rested so well oneSunday night, t␀at the doctoreon Monday
   e morning pronounced him out of danger. About eleven he
  e baltered for thebworse. His little sweetbcountenance
   e assumed an appearance of eagerness, and about twelve he
  e bwas manifestlybconvulsed,bthough not strongly. Onethis,
   e our doctorecalled in another skilful medical man, who
  e bhappened to be at the station, and new medicines were tried
   e which promised partial relief, and the fond mother began
  e bagain to hope. About twelve on Monday night, he was in
   e great pain, and the work of death was evidentlybrapidly
  e bgoing on. We commended him to our covenant God in prayer.
  e bI pleaded, as well as I was able,bHis promise to be the
  e bGod of our seed, as well as our own God.bI prayed for the
  e bchild as a member of Christ‚Äôs mystical body andba branch
   e ofbthe true Vine; and besought t␀at the suffering child
   e might be remembered in the suffering Christ. Our prayers
  e bwere mercifully heard, and our babe from t␀at time suffered
  e bcomparatively little. About five on the morning of the 7th,
   e hisbsoul seemed longing to mount upward. We again in prayer
  e bcommended him to our covenant God, and about half-past

  e bsigh.

  e b‚ÄúIt seemed to me inconceivable that my mind should ever
  e bhave become sobconfused respecting the truths of Scripture.
  e bDuring the whole of Tuesday, and on Tuesday night

  e bshould escape me. My God ever graciously kept me from
  e bbringing a reproach on the principles I preach: but O! I
  e bseem only now tobhave begun to understand many of them. I
   e now know what is meant by the _bread_ of affliction, and
  e bthe _water_ of adversity: I now understand the 38th Psalm

  e b‚ÄúI hope the bitterness of this death is past to us both,
  e bthough our bereavement (as I conceive it ought not) will

  e bthoughts from the lovely object that bound our affections

  e bmourn our sad loss. My understanding yesterday received
   e a lesson from Anna. When weesat down to the ceremony of
  e bdinner, she became raving forewater. Sometimesbit was ‚ÄòDear
  e bpapa, give Nana some water.‚Äô Thenbwith a curtsey to nurse,
  e b‚ÄòPlease Nan, give Nana some water.‚Äô Thenbwith anger crying
   e forewater; but though our hearts were bleeding foreher
  e bdistress, webwould not give her water foreher hurt. Thus,
   e thought I, our heavenly Father is looking down upon us.
 ␀␀␀␀He heard our prayers, our tears for the life of our babe;
 ␀␀␀␀He saw our distress, and He doubtless pitied, but foreour
  e bgood, denies our desires. Oh, maybthe Holy Spirit send home
  e bthe lesson effectually!

  e b‚ÄúOn entering the pulpit oneSunday morning in heaviness of
   e heart, when I pronounced the sentence ‚ÄòOur Father which art
  e bin heaven,‚Äô it powerfully came to my mind, ‚ÄòIs he less a
   e Father than thou art, t␀at he should not care for thee and
  e bthybchild?‚Äô Lord! I believe, help my unbelief!‚Äù

In acknowledging the christian sympathybof Captain Peevor, expressed

  e b‚ÄúWe try to realize the truths you kindlybbring before us;

Itbwas now, also, t␀at Mr. Corrie communicated with

  e b‚ÄúYou will see by the date, wherebI am stationed.bThe place

This extension of the British rule in India, by opening outbwider

  e b‚ÄúI write now to acquaint you with the death of one of our

  e bhis influence, if it can avail--and may God grant, for the
   e honoreof his gospel inethese lands, t␀at a true minister
  e bof his word maybbe sent out. It is inconceivable to those
  e bnot on the spot, how much pious _well-educated_ men may
   e effect, above the usual run, even of pious men who come
  e bout as missionaries.bIf translations be to supply the gift
  e bof tongues, then those translations ought to come as near
  e bthe character of that gift as possible. Now the Serampore
  e btranslations all, I fear, fail entirely ineidiom and
  e bevery recommendation. Of their Hindoostanee translation,
  e bI can speak from some knowledge, that it is calculated to
  e bdisplease the least fastidious, by the mixture of Persian,
  e bArabic, and English words ineit, as well as by the turn
   e given to many phrases, from the literal rendering from
  e bthe English.bThus, ‚Äòon these twobhang all the law and the
  e bprophets,‚Äô the word usedbis literally,b‚Äòsuspended as from a
  e bpeg.‚Äô Such is my own feeling respecting this translation,
  e bthat Ibshould abstain from giving it to an intelligent
  e bHindoo, and no other could make anything of it; and at
  e bthis place, we have, in consequence, nothing to meet the
   e enquiries of the Hindoos, except a catechism translated by
  e bMr. Bowley, which is read with avidity.

  e b‚ÄúDivine providence is, I hope, opening abdoor of great
  e busefulness here, through the means of the Baboo Joy
  e bNarian--a kind ofbDeist,bwho is about giving up a house,
   e and ¬£5,000. to endow it as a school,bto our Church
  e bMissionary Society. The house in Benares we have actual
   e possession of, and it is now undergoing a little repair,
  e bwith a view to commence a school of general learning, of
  e bwhich Mr. Adlington will be the superintendent.‚Äù

The name of JoybNarain will be remembered, as that of the rich native
at Benares, who, some years ago, sent a letter and a benefaction
to the Bible Society.[105] It appears that the same benevolent
individual had at that time formed, also, t␀e design of building and
endowing abfree-school,bby means of which the poorer classes of his
countrymen might receive education.[106]␀He seems tobhave gone so
far as tobhave himself drawn up a plan of the institution, tobhave
commenced building a suitable house, and to have offered to pay for
the support of a schoolmaster and assistants; but, from some cause
or other, nothing had been definitely settled up to the time that
Mr. Corrie was appointed chaplain at Benares, after his return from
England.bSoon after Mr. C.‚Äôs arrival at that station, however, Joy
Narain brought the subject of the free-school before him; and the
following extract from a letter addressed by Mr. C. to the committee
of the Church Missionary Society, gives the substance of whatbpassed
between JoybNarain and himself:--

  e b‚ÄúHe proposes giving a large house in the city for a school,
   e endowing itbwith 200 Rs.ba month, (about ¬£300. a year,)
  e bMr. Adlington to be the teacher.bI suggested tobhim to
  e blet us have the house on Mr. Adlington‚Äôs arrival [from
  e bAgra,] to begin operations; and that for the present Mr.
 ␀␀␀␀Abshould derive his support from the Church Missionary
  e bSociety, whilst he (JoybNarain,)bshould pay for books and
  e bincidental expenses.bThis seemed tobdelight him.bI proposed
  e bthat he should make the Church Missionary Society‚Äôs
  e bcommittee trusteeseof his endowment; reserving tobhimself
  e bthe approval of their agent, who, if approved ofbat the
   e end of one year, should be confirmed for life; or, during
  e bconformity with the rules of the endowment; which, I
  e bproposed, should be for general learning: our Missionary
  e bto be at liberty to receive enquirers after truth, in his
  e bprivate apartments, after school-hours.‚Äù

Toethese several propositions, JoybNarain cordially assented, and
although at the date of the foregoing letter to Mr. Simeon, the
property was not legally made over, yet the school-house had been
put into the possession of the Church Missionary Society. The school
itself was opened on Monday, July 17, 1818, under the superintendence
of Mr. Adlington; the second master being abyoung man, country-born,
but educatedbin England, and intimately acquainted with the
colloquial language and manners of the natives. Mr. Corrie observes,
however, to the Committee of the Church Missionary Society:--

  e b‚ÄúTo give full effect to this gift of JoybNarain, you must
  e bsend us one or twobmen of as good education as possible,
   e and as soon as you can find them.bT␀e disposition to
  e bhear and receive the word, is increasing daily among the
  e bnatives. Many of the rich and learned Hindoos, especially
  e bof this city, seem ready to welcome the gospel.‚Äù

And again to the Committee in Calcutta:--

  e b‚ÄúA man of learning should by all means be sent out to that
  e bschool,bboth to release Mr. Adlington, and to occupy a
   e postbthan which there is none more conspicuous in all the
   e sphere of missionary labour; and, it ought, therefore, to
  e bbe supplied accordingly.‚Äù

Itbwas whilst engaged in watching over the first beginningsbof this
Institution, that Mr. Corrie wrote tobhis brother,

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   ‚ÄúJuly 29, 1818.

  e b‚ÄúThis country becomes daily more and more interesting to
  e bthe christian. The paramount influence of our government
  e bnow seems tobhold out some degree ofbpermanency to our
    erule; and, in consequence, the natives are less embarrassed
  e bwith the fear of the return of former superiors; and
  e bthe consequentbpersecution that would have followed any
  e battention to our religion. Considerate men among them,
   e therefore, begin to speak out their dissatisfaction with
  e bIdolatry; and to enquire whatbbetter we have toboffer
  e bthem.bThis disposition is mostbprovidentially met by the
   e institutions which have risen amongst us of late: and
  e bthe hand of God in disposing all thingsbfor the spread
  e bof His truth, seems evidently displayed.bFirst, there
  e bis the Diocesan Committee, which confines itself to
  e bsupplying those only who understand English, with bibles,
   e prayer-books, and tracts. Next, the Church Missionary
  e bSociety, which supplies the native christians with bibles,
   e and prayer-books in the native languages: as well as
  e bits more direct objects. Then the School-Book Society,
  e bwhich supplies elementary books in all languages, for
   e all description ofbpersons; and then the glorious Bible
  e bSociety, like the ‚Äòlion which covereth,‚Äô embracing all
  e bclasses and climes, in t␀e distribution of the words
  e bof life eternal.bIf to these be added, the labours of
  e bmissionarieseof different denominations, itbwill appear
  e bthat the kingdom of God is near to India. Of missionaries,
   e however, we have as yet, but a scanty supply. May the Lord
  e bof the harvest, thrust forth labourers into India.

  e b‚ÄúIn the beginning of this month I baptized, at Chunar, a
  e bBrahmin, and a Moonshee, in the presence of the native
  e bchristian congregation, and of many Heathen and Mahomedans.
  e bThe Brahmin declared that he had visited all the places
  e breputed holy by Hindoos, from Brindrinath in the borders
  e bof the snowy mountains in the N. W., to Juggernauth in
  e bthe lower partseof Bengal, but found nothing on which his

  e bhe found all the Hindoos in error, and plainly told them
  e bso; in proof ofbhis being in earnest, [he] broke off the
  e bBrahmin‚Äôs cord, (or, as he calledbit, ‚Äòthe lying cord,‚Äô)
  e bbefore them all. The Moonshee bore a similar testimony
  e brespecting the insufficiency of the Mahomedan faith.[107]
  e bThree more are waitingbfor my next visit to Chunar in

  e bcircumstances; may God grant us his blessing to improve
  e bthem tobhis glory!‚Äù

But besides relating such encouraging circumstances as these, Mr.

  e b‚ÄúWe are going on as usual here, doing a little: ‚Äòunknown
   e and yet well known.‚Äô Severalbof the highbNatives have
  e bvisited me lately; chiefly from the intimacy they
  e bperceived Mr. Bird[108] had formedbwith us; but it led,
   e though they meant it not, to religious discussions. A near
  e brelation of the Rajah of Benares, took away yesterday a
  e bHindoostanee New Testament, and Hindoostanee Prayer-book,
  e bwith evident desire, after a long discussion on subjects
  e bconnectedbwith them.‚Äù

And, again, in writingbto the same relative in the month of October,
Mr. C. observes:--

  e b‚ÄúJoybNarain‚Äôs school goeseon very well. Many of good
  e bcaste and familybnow come for instruction in English. The
   e enquiries they make on religious subjects, have led to the
   e conviction, in several, of the follybof idolatry. Indeed, I
  e bam obliged to refrain at times from talking with them, lest

The school here mentioned, having, by Deed, bearing date Oct. 21,
1818, been legally placed under the control of the Calcutta Committee
of the Church Missionary Society and their successors, Mr. Corrie
was requested by JoybNarain to draw up, in English, a detailed
statement of the plan and objects contemplated by the school. A
draft of the statement was, in t␀e first instance, [11th Nov. 1818.]
submitted by Mr. Corrie to the Agent of the Government at Benares,
and was afterwards translated into severalbof the languages of the
country, and circulated among the natives of India. As illustrative
of a remarkable moral movement, towards the maturing of which the
subject of these memoirs materially contributed, the document is too
important to be omitted.

  e b‚ÄúThe following statement of the object and plan of the
   e Institution, is published, with a view to engage such
  e bsupport as may enable the managers to extend to the utmost
  e bthe benefits it is intended to convey.

  e b‚Äú1. In this school, four languages are taught, viz.
  e bEnglish, Persian, Hindoostanee and Bengalee.

  e b‚Äú2. For the purpose of affording instruction in these
  e blanguages, an English master, as superintendent of the
   e Institution, is engaged; proper assistance and learned
  e bteachers in t␀e other languages respectively, are also
  e bretained.

  e b‚Äú3.bIt is intended to maintain, as well as educate, a
  e bnumber of poor boys, who are to be accommodated in the
   e house, as soon as proper arrangements can be made, and a
  e bsmall daily allowance will be made to such poor boys as
  e bcannot be received into the house, to such extent as the
  e bfunds may admit of.

  e b‚Äú4. The benefits of the Institution to be at the same
  e btime open to all who are desirous of availing themselves
  e bof them, without regard to caste or country; and for this
  e bpurpose,bteachers, paper, pens and ink, will be provided
  e bgratis, for all the scholars; it being left to the option
  e bof such parents as can afford to pay for their children‚Äôs
   e education, to contribute at their pleasure to the general
   e expenses of the school, and thereby to extend the benefits
  e bof itbfurther to the poor.

  e b‚Äú5. The primary design of teaching the above languages
  e bbeing, to enable industrious youths to obtain for
  e bthemselves a comfortable livelihood, the first care
  e bwill be to instruct the scholars in reading and writing
  e bgrammatically, and in the most necessary rules of
   e arithmetic; together with the government regulations on the
  e bsubjects of police, and ordinary affairs: after which such
  e byouths as desire further improvement, may be instructed in
   e general history, geography, and astronomy.

  e b‚Äú6. No scholar to be admitted into the school under seven
  e byears of age, except such as are on t␀e foundation, nor any
  e bto be admitted to receive maintenance from the funds who
  e bare above eighteen years. Each scholar to remain in school,
   e if practicable, at least twobyears, but no scholar to
  e breceive pecuniary support beyond the period of seven years,
  e bnor above the age of twenty, unless for the pursuit of some
  e bstudy approved by the managers.

  e b‚Äú7. All the scholars are required to attend regularlybevery
  e bday, to abstain from all improper language in school, and
  e bto maintain a respectable moral character in society;
  e bwithout which no scholar can be admitted, or if admitted,
  e bbe retained on his ill conduct being discovered.

  e b‚Äú8. The school to be open to all visitorsbevery Tuesday,
  e band all contributors to the funds to be admitted to inspect
  e bthe accounts on t␀e second Tuesday in every month.

  e b‚ÄúIt being intended to form a library and museum also
  e bconnected with the school, as soon as practicable, any
  e bdonation of natural curiosities, or of books, in English,
  e bor in anybof the languages of India, (especially grammars,
  e bdictionaries, and books of history)bwill be thankfully
  e breceived; and a book will be kept in which the names of
   e donors will be recorded, with the nature and extent of the
   e donation.‚Äù

  e b   e b   e b   e b   e b   e ‚ÄúBenares, 11th November, 1818.‚Äù

At the time the foregoing statement was put into circulation, there
were no less than one hundred and sixteen scholars in the school; but
it had already become apparent that the monthly sum granted by the
founder, was by no means sufficient to meet the necessary expenses of
the establishment. Joy Narain therefore, made a formal application to
the Governor-General in council for pecuniary assistance, when Lord
Hastings, with the ready attention which he always manifested for
the moral improvement of India, ordered a regular monthly allowance
to be contributed from the funds of government toward the efficient
maintenance of the school.

But the residence of Mr. Corrie at Benares was now drawing to a
close. He received about this time, an appointment to the vacant
Chaplaincy at Cawnpore; but before he could proceed to that station,
a vacancy had occurred at the Presidency by the departure of the
senior chaplain on sick-leave. This event was t␀e occasion of Mr.
Corrie‚Äôs recall to Calcutta. He accordingly left Benares in December
1818, amid the regrets of a large body of respectable natives, who
had seen so much reason for regarding him as the friend and promoter
of every institution which was calculated to promote their welfare.
It could not, therefore, but be a matter of gratification to him, to
be followed to Calcutta by the subjoined Address written in English,
Persian, Hindoostanee, and Bengalee:--


  e b   e b   e b  FROM THE INHABITANTS OF BENARES,

  e b   e b   e b   e b TO THE REV. D. CORRIE.

  e b‚ÄúFor severalbyears past we have entertained a desire,
  e bthat no one would indulge in anybkind of controversy, and
  e bthat all theological discussion might cease amongst us.
  b  For the attainment of this our desire, Joy Narain Maharaj,
  e boften attempted to establish a school, but was never able
  e bto accomplish his design. When you arrived at Benares,
  e band kindlybengaged the superintendence of a school, in
   e the which instruction should be afforded in the English,
  e bPersian, Hindue and Bengalee languages, from that time
  e bour wishes began to be realized: seeing that as at all
  e btimes it is a difficult thing to collect individuals of
   e different religious principles, you bybyour investigation,
    eliberality and kindness, &c. caused upwards of 200 to lay
  e baside their religious prejudices and engage in the same
  e bpursuit. Since when, by the will of God, you were pleased
  e bto embark for Calcutta,byour condescension, liberality,
  e band charity; your kindness, love for the truth, and enmity
  e bto deception;byour excellent understanding, convincing
  e bknowledge, and acquaintance with the theological works

  e bof dailybconversation, and cause us to admire that prudence
  e bwhich, aloof from the violence made use of by those of
   e other dynasties, causes Rajahs, Baboos, greatband learned
  e bPundits, Mouluwees, Moonshees, in fact the greatbof the

  e bthings occasions much sorrow, and produces a desire for
  e banother interview. Here we trust that God Almightybwill
  e bagain suffer us to meet, and that as long as it please Him
  e bto retain you in Calcutta,bHe will not fail on your account
  e bto bless both us and the school.‚Äù

  e b(Here follow the signatures of Joy Narain and of 266 other
  e bnatives of Benares.)


  e b  [95] Formed in 1815.

  e b  [96] Instituted May 1817.

  e b  [97] Originated by natives in Aug. 1816.

  e b  [98] Established in 1789.

  e b  [99] See Missionary Register for 1818, p. 448.

  e b [100] A kind of footman.

  e b [101] Mr. Adlington had gone to Agra to visit Abdool
