the Archdeacon and Clergy. The pall was borne by six gentlemen of
rank; and the Governor of the Presidency followed as Chief Mourner,

Bishop was deposited by the side of Mrs. Corrie, and within a few

On Monday, 6th February, the Governor in Council issued an Order

Grammar School now resolved also, that t␀␀ir Institution should in

accordingly been raised sufficient for the purposes specified, a

Weekes, which is now in the Cathedral of Madras.

Nor were the Calcutta friends of the deceased Bishop backward
to testify their regard for his worth. For at a public meeting,
which was held on t␀␀ 16th March, in the Town Hall, Bishop Wilson
being in t␀␀ chair, it was resolved to solicit subscriptions for
t␀e purpose of erecting marble slabs, bot␀ in t␀␀ old Church and

t␀e purchase of a Portrait of him. It was, moreover, resolved to

‚ÄúBishop Corrie‚Äôs Scholarships.‚Äù[188] And all these tokens of respect
were in due time effected.␀
In Ceylon, also, a general meeting was called at the King‚Äôs house,
Colombo, by His Excellency the Governor, at which, subscriptions were
entered into for the purpose of erecting a monument to t␀e Bishop‚Äôs
memory in St. Peter‚Äôs Church, Colombo, and for founding scholarships,
which should bear his name, in the Grammar School at Madras. Bot␀
which objects were accomplished.[189]␀
Thus terminated the eart␀ly labours of the first Bishop of Madras,
after a brief but not unimportant episcopate, if a judgment may be
formed from the amount of good effected, from the general gloom which
t␀e Bishop‚Äôs decease cast over the whole Presidency, and the respect
with which his memory was cherished. To t␀ose who were intimately
acquainted with Bishop Corrie, it will not excite surprise that his
death should have called forth all the public manifestations of
sorrow and respect, which have here been recited. For after making
every abatement for that human sinfulness and infirmity from which ␀␀
was not exempt, there still remained to him more than an ordinary
share of natural kindness of heart, benevolence of disposition, and
warmth of affection; so that he could not but be generally beloved.␀Nor will the reader of t␀ese pages be disposed to question that
Bishop Corrie will long be remembered in India, as t␀e man of God,
through w␀ose instrumentality originated much of the moral good
which, since his time, has been slowly spreading itself over that
land of darkness and superstition.[190] But chiefly, it is believed,
will his name he held in honour throughout our Eastern Empire, as
one of that small band of heroic spirits who, in self-devotion to
Christ and zeal for the extension of the Redeemer‚Äôs kingdom, manfully
struggled against difficulties and discouragements of which we can
form but an inadequate estimate:--who never suffered themselves to
doubt but that t␀␀ cause they had by grace espoused would still go
on and prosper, until ‚Äúat the name of Jesus every knee should bow,
and every tongue confess that He is Lord, unto the glory of God the
Father.‚Äù␀␀␀

␀                                  I.

The following notice appeared in the Government Gazette of Feb. 7th,
1837:--␀␀␀‚ÄúWith feelings of unfeigned sorrow, the Right Honorable the Governor
in Council, records the demise of the Right Rev. the Lord Bishop of
Madras. T␀e Venerable Prelate expired at half past three o‚Äôclock, on
the morning of Sunday last. As a tribute of respect to his memory,
the flag of the garrison was hoisted half-staff-high during the day,
and on the funeral procession leaving his Lordship‚Äôs late residence,
fifty-nine minute guns, corresponding with the age of the deceased,
were fired from the Fort battery.

‚ÄúHis Lordship‚Äôs remains were attended to the grave by the Right
Honorable the Governor, the Judges of the Supreme Court, His
Excellency the Commander-in-chief, t␀e members of Council, all the
principal civil and military functionaries at t␀␀ Presidency, and
an immense concourse of all classes of the community; desirous of

benevolence and exemplary conduct of t␀e Bishop, had universally
inspired.␀␀␀‚ÄúPublished by order of the Right Honourable the Governor in Council.
␀                               ‚Äú(Signed) H. Chamier, Chief Secretary.‚Äù␀␀␀

     At a public Meeting of the friends of the late Bishop of

␀ ␀␀␀␀1st. That t␀is Meeting has heard with the deepest regret of

                                  V.␀␀
The preceding pages bear sufficient testimony to the zeal and
activity of Bishop Corrie, in forwarding every plan for securing
a Christian education to the youth of India. But it is well
known among the deceased Prelate‚Äôs friends, that he was in the
habit of translating and compiling school-books for the use of
such Hindoostanee schools as more immediately came under his own
superintendance. It is a matter of regret that the many enquiries
which the Editors of these Memoirs have made, with a view to
obtaining a definite list of the books in question, have been but
partially successful. It may, however, be mentioned that besides
translating into Hindoostanee, Sellon‚Äôs Abridgment of Scripture,␀Watts‚Äô Catechism, The Assembly‚Äôs Shorter Catechism, portions of
Milner‚Äôs Church History, &c., the Bishop drew up in English, ‚ÄúA
general Outline of Ancient History,‚Äù for the use of the Hindoostanee
youth. A third Edition of t␀is ‚ÄúOutline‚Äù was going through the press
at t␀e time of the Bishop‚Äôs death; and other Editions have since
t␀en been printed. Among his papers was found, also, a manuscript
translation into Hindoostanee of a brief Church History, by t␀e Rev.␀E. Sims, entitled ‚ÄúChristian Records.‚Äù
